verses.text: The scroll of the lineage of Jesus the Messiah, the son of David, the son of Abraham.
Abraham fathered Isaac, Isaac fathered Jacob, and Jacob fathered Judah and his brothers.
Judah fathered Perez and Zerah by Tamar, Perez fathered Hezron, and Hezron fathered Ram.
Ram fathered Amminadab, Amminadab fathered Nahshon, and Nahshon fathered Salmon.
Salmon fathered Boaz by Rahab, Boaz fathered Obed by Ruth, and Obed fathered Jesse.
Jesse fathered David the king. David fathered Solomon by the wife of Uriah.
Solomon fathered Rehoboam, Rehoboam fathered Abijah, and Abijah fathered Asaph.
Asaph fathered Jehoshaphat, Jehoshaphat fathered Joram, and Joram fathered Uzziah.
Uzziah fathered Jotham, Jotham fathered Ahaz, and Ahaz fathered Hezekiah.
Hezekiah fathered Manasseh, Manasseh fathered Amos, and Amos fathered Josiah.
Josiah fathered Jechoniah and his brothers at the time of the deportation to Babylon.
After the deportation to Babylon, Jechoniah fathered Shealtiel, and Shealtiel fathered Zerubbabel.
Zerubbabel fathered Abiud, Abiud fathered Eliakim, and Eliakim fathered Azor.
Azor fathered Zadok, Zadok fathered Achim, and Achim fathered Eliud.
Eliud fathered Eleazar, Eleazar fathered Matthan, and Matthan fathered Jacob.
Jacob fathered Joseph, the husband of Mary, from whom was born Jesus, who is called the Messiah.

So all the generations from Abraham to David were fourteen generations, and from David to the deportation to Babylon were fourteen generations, and from the deportation to Babylon to the Messiah were fourteen generations.
This is how the birth of Jesus the Messiah came about: When his mother Mary was betrothed to Joseph, before they came together, she was found to be pregnant from the Holy Spirit.
Because Joseph her husband was a man committed to the Law and yet did not want to disgrace her publicly, he intended to divorce her quietly.

But after he had considered these things, look—an angel of the Lord appeared to him in a dream, saying, [ANGEL]“Joseph, son of David, do not be afraid to take Mary as your wife, for what has been conceived in her is from the Holy Spirit.
She will give birth to a son, and you are to name him ‘Jesus,’ for he himself will save his people from their sins.”[/ANGEL]

Now all this happened so that what was spoken by the Lord through the prophet might be fulfilled: [SCRIPTURE]“Look, the virgin will be pregnant and will give birth to a son, and they will name him Immanuel”[/SCRIPTURE]—which means, when translated, “God with us.”
When Joseph woke up from his sleep, he did as the angel of the Lord had commanded him and took her as his wife.
But he did not have intimate relations with her until she had given birth to a son; and he named him Jesus.

chapters.notes:
**“The scroll of the lineage” (v. 1)**: The Greek *Biblos geneseōs* echoes the Septuagint’s phrasing in Genesis 2:4 and 5:1. It suggests not just a "family tree" but a "record of origins" or "account of the new creation" beginning with Jesus.

**The Genealogy (v. 2–16)**: The Greek *egennēsen* ("fathered" or "begat") is used consistently in the active voice for the men, but the pattern breaks in verse 16. There, the verb becomes passive (*egen nēthē*—"was born/begotten") and refers back to Mary (*ex hēs*, feminine singular). This grammatically excludes Joseph from the biological fatherhood of Jesus, maintaining the narrative of the virginal conception.

**“Asaph” and “Amos” (v. 7, 10)**: Following the SBLGNT/NA28 critical text, these names appear as the psalmist/prophet names rather than the kings "Asa" and "Amon." Matthew may have used these spellings intentionally or followed a specific tradition of the royal list.

**“Deportation” (v. 11, 12, 17)**: *Metoikesia* refers to a forced change of abode or migration. "Exile" is a common translation, but "deportation" captures the political reality of the Babylonian action.

**“A man committed to the Law” (v. 19)**: The Greek *dikaios* is traditionally "just" or "righteous." In a first-century Jewish context, this specifically means someone who is observant of the Torah. Joseph’s dilemma is that the Law (Deut. 22:20–21) seems to require public exposure, yet his "righteousness" is tempered by a desire for mercy, leading to the decision for a "quiet" divorce.

**“Jesus” / “He will save” (v. 21)**: This is a direct wordplay that an Aramaic or Hebrew speaker would immediately recognize. The name *Iēsous* (from the Hebrew *Yeshua*) literally means "The LORD saves" or "Salvation." The explanation "for he (*autos*) will save (*sōsei*)" clarifies the meaning of the name.

**“Intimate relations” (v. 25)**: The Greek *eginōsken* ("know") is a standard Semitic euphemism (the Aramaic *yeda*) for sexual intercourse. The translation uses "intimate relations" to make the meaning clear to a modern reader.

verses.text: After Jesus was born in Bethlehem of Judea during the reign of King Herod, Magi from the East arrived in Jerusalem,
asking, [SPEAKER:The Magi]“Where is the one born King of the Judeans? For we saw his star in its rising and have come to do him homage.”[/SPEAKER]
When King Herod heard this, he was deeply shaken, and all Jerusalem was in turmoil along with him.
He called together all the chief priests and the scribes of the people and began inquiring of them where the Messiah was to be born.
They told him, [SPEAKER:The Chief Priests]“In Bethlehem of Judea, for this is what has been written through the prophet:
[SCRIPTURE]‘And you, Bethlehem, in the land of Judah, are by no means least among the rulers of Judah; for from you will come a Ruler who will shepherd my people Israel.’[/SCRIPTURE]”[/SPEAKER]
Then Herod secretly summoned the Magi and determined from them the exact time the star had appeared.
Sending them to Bethlehem, he said, [SPEAKER:Herod]“Go and search carefully for the child. When you find him, report back to me so that I too may go and do him homage.”[/SPEAKER]
After they heard the king, they went on their way; and look—the star they had seen in its rising went ahead of them until it came to a stop over the place where the child was.
When they saw the star, they were filled with an intense, overflowing joy.

They entered the house and saw the child with Mary his mother, and falling to their knees, they did him homage. Then, opening their treasure chests, they presented him with gifts: gold, frankincense, and myrrh.
And having been warned in a dream not to return to Herod, they departed for their own country by a different route.

After they had departed, an angel of the Lord appeared to Joseph in a dream, saying, [ANGEL]“Get up, take the child and his mother, and flee to Egypt. Stay there until I tell you, for Herod is about to search for the child to destroy him.”[/ANGEL]
So Joseph got up, took the child and his mother by night, and withdrew to Egypt.
He remained there until the death of Herod. This took place so that what was spoken by the Lord through the prophet might be fulfilled: [SCRIPTURE]“Out of Egypt I called my son.”[/SCRIPTURE]

When Herod realized he had been outwitted by the Magi, he flew into a violent rage. He sent orders to kill all the boys in Bethlehem and in all its surrounding districts who were two years old and under, based on the precise time he had ascertained from the Magi.
Then what was spoken through Jeremiah the prophet was fulfilled:
[SCRIPTURE]“A voice was heard in Ramah, weeping and great lamentation; Rachel weeping for her children, and she refused to be comforted, because they are no more.”[/SCRIPTURE]
After Herod died, an angel of the Lord appeared in a dream to Joseph in Egypt,
saying, [ANGEL]“Get up, take the child and his mother and go into the land of Israel, for those who were seeking the child’s life are dead.”[/ANGEL]
So he got up, took the child and his mother, and entered the land of Israel.
But when he heard that Archelaus was reigning over Judea in place of his father Herod, he was afraid to go there. Having been warned in a dream, he withdrew to the region of Galilee.
He went and settled in a town called Nazareth, so that what was spoken through the prophets might be fulfilled: [SCRIPTURE]“He will be called a Nazarene.”[/SCRIPTURE]

chapters.notes:
**"Magi" (v. 1, 7, 16)**: The Greek *magoi* refers to a specific class of Zoroastrian priest-astrologers from the Persian/Babylonian region. Translating this as "wise men" or "kings" obscures their historical identity as experts in celestial omens, which is central to why they followed a star.

**"In its rising" (v. 2, 9)**: The Greek *en tē anatolē* is often translated as "in the East," but in an astronomical context, it specifically refers to the heliacal rising of a star (its first appearance on the horizon before sunrise). This explains the Magi's technical observation.

**"Do him homage" (v. 2, 8, 11)**: The verb *proskyneō* denotes the physical act of prostrating oneself or bowing deeply. In this context, it refers to the royal protocol of the Ancient Near East rather than "worship" in the modern, exclusively religious sense.

**"Messiah" (v. 4)**: The Greek *ho christos* is the translation of the Hebrew *Mashiach* (the Anointed One). Using "the Messiah" preserves the Jewish sectarian and political expectations Herod was investigating.

**"The child" (v. 8, 9, 11, 13, 14, 20)**: The Greek *paidion* denotes a young child or toddler, as opposed to *brephos* (infant/newborn). This aligns with Herod’s order to kill boys up to two years old (v. 16), suggesting some time had passed since the birth.

**"Outwitted" (v. 16)**: *Enepaichthē* literally means "was played with" or "mocked." In this context, it carries the sense of being made a fool of or tricked by the Magi’s failure to report back.

**"Nazarene" (v. 23)**: Matthew cites "the prophets" (plural), yet no specific Old Testament verse says the Messiah will be called a "Nazarene." This is likely a wordplay on the Hebrew *netzer* ("branch") from Isaiah 11:1, or perhaps an allusion to the *nazir* (Nazirite) tradition. Because the Greek *Nazōraios* preserves this phonetic link, it is retained.

verses.text: In those days, John the Baptizer presents himself, heralding a message in the Judean wilderness,
saying, [SPEAKER:John the Baptist]"Turn your hearts back to God, for the Kingdom of the Heavens has come near."[/SPEAKER]
This is the man spoken of through the prophet Isaiah, who said: [SCRIPTURE]“The voice of one shouting in the wilderness: ‘Prepare the way of the Lord; make his paths straight.’”[/SCRIPTURE]
John himself wore clothing made of camel’s hair with a leather belt around his waist, and his food was locusts and wild honey.
At that time, Jerusalem, all Judea, and the entire region along the Jordan were streaming out to him.
They were being baptized by him in the Jordan River as they openly confessed their sins.
But when he saw many of the Pharisees and Sadducees coming to his baptism, he said to them, [SPEAKER:John the Baptist]"You spawn of vipers! Who warned you to flee from the coming wrath?
Therefore, produce fruit that proves your heart has truly turned.
And do not presume to say to yourselves, ‘We have Abraham as our father,’ for I tell you that God is able to raise up children for Abraham from these very stones.
Even now the axe lies at the root of the trees; therefore, every tree that does not produce good fruit is cut down and thrown into the fire.

I, for my part, baptize you in water for the turning of your hearts; but the one coming after me is more powerful than I am—I am not even worthy to carry his sandals. He will baptize you in the Holy Spirit and fire.
His winnowing shovel is in his hand, and he will thoroughly clear his threshing floor; he will gather his wheat into the storehouse, but the chaff he will burn up with unquenchable fire."[/SPEAKER]
Then Jesus comes from Galilee to the Jordan to John, to be baptized by him.
But John tried to prevent him, saying, [SPEAKER:John the Baptist]"I have need to be baptized by you, and yet you come to me?"[/SPEAKER]
Jesus answered him, [JESUS]"Let it be so for now; for in this way it is fitting for us to fulfill every requirement of God’s righteousness."[/JESUS] Then John allowed him.
As soon as Jesus was baptized, he came up out of the water; and suddenly the heavens were opened, and he saw the Spirit of God descending like a dove and coming upon him.
And a voice came from the heavens, saying, [GOD]"This is my Son, the Beloved, in whom I take great delight."[/GOD]

chapters.notes:
**"Turn your hearts back to God" (v. 2, 8, 11)**: The Greek *metanoia* is traditionally "repentance," but in the context of John’s Jewish audience, it evokes the Hebrew *teshuva* (returning to God). It is not merely a feeling of remorse but a total reorientation of one’s life and priorities.

**"Kingdom of the Heavens" (v. 2)**: Matthew preserves the plural "heavens" (*tōn ouranōn*), reflecting the Hebrew/Aramaic idiom. It also honors the Jewish practice of using "Heaven" as a reverent metonym for God.

**"Spawn of vipers" (v. 7)**: The Greek *gennēmata* refers to offspring or brood. It suggests that the religious leaders are not just behaving like snakes, but share the very nature of the "serpent" from the beginning.

**"Stones/Children" (v. 9)**: This is a clear Aramaic/Hebrew wordplay that the original audience would recognize: God can raise up "children" (*banim*) from "stones" (*abanim*).

**"Carry his sandals" (v. 11)**: Carrying or removing sandals was the task of the lowest slave. John is emphasizing the vast qualitative difference between his own authority and that of the coming Messiah.

**"Winnowing shovel" (v. 12)**: The *ptyon* was a wooden fork or shovel used to throw threshed grain into the air so the wind could blow away the lighter chaff (*achyron*), leaving the heavier grain to fall on the threshing floor.

**"Every requirement of God’s righteousness" (v. 15)**: The term *dikaiosynē* here refers to "covenant faithfulness" or "doing what is right in God’s eyes." Jesus is not suggesting he is a sinner who needs repentance, but that his submission to John’s baptism is a necessary step in God’s unfolding plan of salvation.

**"The Beloved" (v. 17)**: The Greek *ho agapētos* is more than an adjective; it functions as a Messianic title. It alludes to the "beloved son" Isaac (Genesis 22) and the "Servant" of God (Isaiah 42:1), signaling that Jesus is the unique heir and the one who will suffer.

verses.text: Then Jesus was led up into the wilderness by the Spirit to be tested by the Slanderer.
After he had fasted for forty days and forty nights, he was famished.
The Tester approached him and said, [SPEAKER:The Slanderer]“If you are the Son of God, speak so that these stones become loaves of bread.”[/SPEAKER]
But Jesus answered, [JESUS]“It stands written: [SCRIPTURE]‘A person shall not live on bread alone, but on every utterance that comes out through the mouth of God.’[/SCRIPTURE]”[/JESUS]
Then the Slanderer took him into the Holy City and stood him on the highest parapet of the temple.

He said to him, [SPEAKER:The Slanderer]“If you are the Son of God, throw yourself down; for it stands written: [SCRIPTURE]‘He will give his messengers orders concerning you,’[/SCRIPTURE] and [SCRIPTURE]‘on their hands they will lift you up, so that you do not even strike your foot against a stone.’[/SCRIPTURE]”[/SPEAKER]
Jesus said to him, [JESUS]“Again, it stands written: [SCRIPTURE]‘You shall not put the Lord your God to the test.’[/SCRIPTURE]”[/JESUS]
Again, the Slanderer took him to a very high mountain and showed him all the kingdoms of the world and their splendor.
He said to him, [SPEAKER:The Slanderer]“All these things I will give to you, if you will fall down and worship me.”[/SPEAKER]
Then Jesus said to him, [JESUS]“Be gone, Satan! For it stands written: [SCRIPTURE]‘You shall worship the Lord your God, and him alone shall you serve with sacred duty.’[/SCRIPTURE]”[/JESUS]
Then the Slanderer left him, and suddenly, messengers from God arrived and began to wait on him.
Now when Jesus heard that John had been handed over to custody, he withdrew into Galilee.
Leaving Nazareth, he went and settled in Capernaum by the sea, in the regions of Zebulun and Naphtali.
This happened so that what was spoken through Isaiah the prophet might be fulfilled:
[SCRIPTURE]“Land of Zebulun and land of Naphtali, the way of the sea, beyond the Jordan, Galilee of the nations—
the people sitting in darkness have seen a great light, and for those sitting in the region and shadow of death, a light has dawned upon them.”[/SCRIPTURE]
From that time on, Jesus began to proclaim his message, saying, [JESUS]“Change your hearts and minds, for the kingdom of the heavens has come near.”[/JESUS]
While walking along the Sea of Galilee, he saw two brothers—Simon (the one called Peter) and his brother Andrew—casting a circular net into the sea, for they were fishermen.
He said to them, [JESUS]“Come, follow behind me, and I will make you fishers of people.”[/JESUS]
Immediately, they left their nets and followed him.
Going on from there, he saw two other brothers—James the son of Zebedee and his brother John—in the boat with Zebedee their father, mending their nets. He called them,
and immediately they left the boat and their father and followed him.
Jesus traveled throughout the whole of Galilee, teaching in their synagogues, proclaiming the good news of the kingdom, and healing every kind of disease and every kind of infirmity among the people.

News about him spread into the whole of Syria. They brought to him all those who were suffering—those racked with various diseases and torments, those possessed by demons, those who were moon-struck, and those who were paralyzed—and he healed them.
Large crowds followed him from Galilee, the Decapolis, Jerusalem, Judea, and from beyond the Jordan.

chapters.notes:
**"The Slanderer" (v. 1, 5, 8, 11)**: The Greek *diabolos* literally means "one who throws [insults/accusations] across." While "Devil" is the traditional English derivative, "Slanderer" or "Accuser" captures the functional role this figure plays in the divine court and in this narrative of testing.

**"Tested" (v. 1, 3, 7)**: The verb *peirazō* can mean "tempt" (solicit to sin) or "test" (prove the quality of). Given the echoes of Israel’s forty-year testing in the wilderness, "test" or "prove" is the primary sense here.

**"Every utterance" (v. 4)**: The Greek *rhēmati* refers to a specific spoken word or thing said, rather than the more abstract *logos*. It emphasizes that life is sustained by the ongoing, active speech of God.

**"Highest parapet" (v. 5)**: *Pterugion* literally means "little wing." In an architectural context, it refers to the highest extremity or a finial/parapet of the temple complex.

**"Messengers" (v. 6, 11)**: The Greek *angeloi* are simply "messengers." While "angels" is a common loanword, it often triggers modern celestial imagery that can obscure their role as God’s agents or couriers.

**"Sacred duty" (v. 10)**: The verb *latreuō* refers specifically to religious service or cultic worship offered to a deity.

**"Handed over" (v. 12)**: *Paredothē* is a significant term in Matthew. It is the same word used later for Jesus being "betrayed" or "delivered up." It carries a weight of judicial or providential handing over to one's fate.

**"Change your hearts and minds" (v. 17)**: The Greek *metanoeite* is traditionally "repent," but "repentance" in modern English often implies merely feeling sorry. The Greek term implies a radical change in one’s *nous* (mind/perspective), leading to a change in the direction of one’s life.

**"Kingdom of the heavens" (v. 17)**: Matthew consistently uses the plural "heavens" (*ouranōn*), following the Hebrew/Aramaic plural *shamayim*. 

**"Moon-struck" (v. 24)**: The Greek *selēniazomenous* literally means to be affected by the moon. While this referred to what we now call epilepsy, the translation retains the original audience's understanding of the condition's source.

verses.text: Seeing the crowds, he went up onto the mountain. After he sat down, his disciples came to him.
Then, opening his mouth to speak, he began to teach them, saying:
[JESUS]"Blessed are those who are poor in spirit, for the kingdom of the heavens belongs to them.
Blessed are those who mourn, for they will be comforted.
Blessed are those who are gentle in their strength, for they will inherit the earth.
Blessed are those who hunger and thirst for righteousness, for they will be satisfied.
Blessed are the merciful, for they will be shown mercy.
Blessed are the pure in heart, for they will see God.
Blessed are the peacemakers, for they will be called sons of God.
Blessed are those who have been persecuted for the sake of righteousness, for the kingdom of the heavens belongs to them.
Blessed are you whenever people insult you and persecute you and say all kinds of evil against you falsely because of me.
Rejoice and be glad, because your reward in the heavens is great; for in the same way they persecuted the prophets who were before you.
You are the salt of the earth. But if the salt loses its zest, how can its saltiness be restored? It is no longer good for anything except to be thrown out and trampled underfoot by people.
You are the light of the world. A city situated on a hill cannot be hidden.
Nor do people light a lamp and put it under a large clay jar, but on a lampstand, and it gives light to everyone in the house.
In the same way, let your light shine before people so that they may see your good works and give glory to your Father who is in the heavens.
Do not think that I came to abolish the Law or the Prophets. I did not come to abolish, but to bring them to their intended fullness.
Truly I tell you, until heaven and earth pass away, not one iota, not one tiny stroke of a letter, will pass from the Law until everything has been accomplished.

Therefore, whoever relaxes even one of the least of these commandments and teaches others to do the same will be called 'least' in the kingdom of the heavens. But whoever practices and teaches them will be called 'great' in the kingdom of the heavens.
For I tell you that unless your righteousness surpasses that of the scholars and Pharisees, you will certainly not enter the kingdom of the heavens.
You have heard that it was said to the ancients, [SCRIPTURE]'You shall not murder,'[/SCRIPTURE] and, [SCRIPTURE]'Whoever murders will be subject to judgment.'[/SCRIPTURE]

But I tell you that everyone who is angry with his brother will be subject to judgment. Whoever says to his brother, 'Empty-head!' will be subject to the High Council; and whoever says, 'You fool!' will be subject to the Gehenna of fire.
So if you are offering your gift at the altar and there remember that your brother has something against you,
leave your gift there in front of the altar and go. First be reconciled to your brother, and then come and offer your gift.

Come to terms quickly with your accuser while you are still on the way to court with him, or your accuser may hand you over to the judge, and the judge to the officer, and you will be thrown into prison.
Truly I tell you, you will never get out of there until you have paid the last cent.
You have heard that it was said, [SCRIPTURE]'You shall not commit adultery.'[/SCRIPTURE]
But I tell you that everyone who looks at a woman with the intent to desire her has already committed adultery with her in his heart.
If your right eye causes you to stumble, tear it out and throw it away. It is better for you to lose one of your members than for your whole body to be thrown into Gehenna.
And if your right hand causes you to stumble, cut it off and throw it away. It is better for you to lose one of your members than for your whole body to go into Gehenna.
It was also said, [SCRIPTURE]'Whoever divorces his wife must give her a certificate of dismissal.'[/SCRIPTURE]
But I tell you that everyone who divorces his wife, except on the ground of sexual immorality, makes her an adulteress; and whoever marries a divorced woman commits adultery.
Again, you have heard that it was said to the ancients, [SCRIPTURE]'You shall not swear falsely, but you shall fulfill your oaths to the Lord.'[/SCRIPTURE]
But I tell you, do not swear at all: neither by heaven, for it is the throne of God;
nor by the earth, for it is the footstool of his feet; nor by Jerusalem, for it is the city of the Great King.
Nor should you swear by your head, because you cannot make a single hair white or black.
Let your 'Yes' mean 'Yes' and your 'No' mean 'No.' Anything beyond this comes from the evil one.
You have heard that it was said, [SCRIPTURE]'An eye for an eye and a tooth for a tooth.'[/SCRIPTURE]
But I tell you, do not violently resist the one who is evil. Instead, whoever slaps you on the right cheek, turn the other to him as well.
To the one who wants to sue you and take your tunic, let him have your cloak also.
And whoever forces you to go one mile, go with him two.
Give to the one who asks of you, and do not turn away from the one who wants to borrow from you.
You have heard that it was said, [SCRIPTURE]'You shall love your neighbor'[/SCRIPTURE] and 'hate your enemy.'
But I tell you, love your enemies and pray for those who persecute you,
so that you may become sons of your Father in the heavens. For he makes his sun rise on the evil and the good, and sends rain on the righteous and the unrighteous.
For if you love only those who love you, what reward do you have? Do not even the tax collectors do the same?
And if you greet only your brothers, what are you doing that is extraordinary? Do not even the Gentiles do the same?
Therefore, you shall be perfectly mature, just as your heavenly Father is perfectly mature."[/JESUS]

chapters.notes:
**"Blessed" (vv. 3–11)**: The Greek *makarioi* implies more than a feeling of happiness; it describes a state of being honored or flourishing under God’s favor. Given the counter-cultural nature of the list, it suggests that those the world considers "losers" are actually the ones God "congratulates."

**"Gentle in their strength" (v. 5)**: This renders *praeis*. In the first century, this was not a "weak" word; it described power that had been tamed or bridled (like a warhorse) or the gentleness of a ruler who has the power to act but chooses kindness.

**"The heavens" (vv. 3, 10, 12, etc.)**: The Greek *tōn ouranōn* is plural, reflecting the Hebrew *shamayim*. Matthew uses this phrase ("Kingdom of the Heavens") as a reverent Jewish circumlocution for "Kingdom of God."

**"Bring them to their intended fullness" (v. 17)**: *Plērōsai* means to fill up or complete. Jesus is not just "keeping" the law; he is bringing it to the destination it was always traveling toward.

**"Iota... stroke" (v. 18)**: The "iota" refers to the *yod*, the smallest Hebrew letter. The "stroke" (*keraia*) refers to the tiny decorative "horn" or serif that distinguishes similar Hebrew letters.

**"Empty-head" / "You fool!" (v. 22)**: *Rhaka* is an Aramaic term of contempt for someone’s intelligence (*reka*). *Mōre* is Greek for "fool" but in a Semitic context, it often carried the weight of the Hebrew *mōreh*, implying a "rebel" against God.

**"Gehenna" (vv. 22, 29, 30)**: This is retained as a loanword. It refers to the Valley of Hinnom (*Ge-Hinnom*) outside Jerusalem, a place associated with child sacrifice in Israel’s past and later used as a smoldering refuse heap. It serves as a vivid metaphor for the destruction of the person.

**"Causes you to stumble" (vv. 29–30)**: The Greek *skandalizei* refers to a trap-spring or a stumbling block that causes a downfall.

**"Do not violently resist" (v. 39)**: The verb *antistēnai* often carries a legal or military connotation of "standing against" or "counter-attacking." Jesus is prohibiting a cycle of violent retaliation.

**"Tunic... cloak" (v. 40)**: The *chitōn* was the inner garment (worn against the skin), while the *himation* was the expensive outer cloak. To give both was to be left naked, shaming the creditor who took a person's basic dignity.

**"Forces you to go one mile" (v. 41)**: This refers to *angareia*, the legal right of a Roman soldier to press a civilian into service to carry their gear for one mile.

**"Perfectly mature" (v. 48)**: *Teleios* does not mean "flawless" in the modern sense but "complete," "whole," or "having reached its end-goal." In the context of v. 45, it refers to an impartial, all-encompassing love that mimics God's own "complete" character.

verses.text: [JESUS]"Be careful not to practice your righteousness before people just to be a spectacle for them. If you do, you have no reward with your Father who is in the heavens.

So, whenever you give to the poor, do not sound a trumpet ahead of yourself, as the performers do in the synagogues and in the streets so that they might be glorified by people. Truly I tell you: they have received their payment in full.
But when you give to the poor, do not let your left hand know what your right hand is doing,
so that your giving may be in secret. And your Father, who sees what is done in secret, will repay you.

And when you pray, you must not be like the performers, because they love to pray standing in the synagogues and on the corners of the wide plazas so that they might be on display for people. Truly I tell you: they have received their payment in full.
But when you pray, go into your innermost room, shut your door, and pray to your Father who is in that secret place. And your Father, who sees what is done in secret, will repay you.
When you pray, do not babble like the nations do, for they think that by their long-windedness they will be heard.
Do not be like them, for your Father knows what things you need before you even ask him.
This, then, is how you should pray: 'Our Father in the heavens, let your name be kept holy.
Let your kingdom come. Let your will be done, as it is in heaven, so also on earth.
Give us today the bread we need for the coming day.
And cancel our debts, as we also have canceled the debts of our debtors.
And do not bring us into the time of trial, but rescue us from the Evil One.'
For if you forgive people for their failures, your heavenly Father will also forgive you.
But if you do not forgive people, neither will your Father forgive your failures.

Whenever you fast, do not put on a gloomy face like the performers. They neglect their appearance so that it is obvious to people they are fasting. Truly I tell you: they have received their payment in full.
But when you fast, anoint your head and wash your face,
so that your fasting is not seen by people but by your Father who is in that hidden place. And your Father, who sees what is done in the hidden place, will repay you.
Do not store up for yourselves treasures on earth, where moth and decay destroy, and where thieves dig through and steal.
Instead, store up for yourselves treasures in heaven, where neither moth nor decay destroys, and where thieves do not dig through or steal.
For where your treasure is, there your heart will be also.
The eye is the lamp of the body. If, then, your eye is sincere, your whole body will be full of light.
But if your eye is malicious, your whole body will be full of darkness. If, then, the light within you is darkness, how great is that darkness!
No one is able to serve two masters. For either he will hate the one and love the other, or he will be devoted to the one and look down on the other. You cannot serve both God and Mammon.
Because of this I tell you: do not be anxious about your life—what you will eat—nor about your body—what you will wear. Is not life more than food, and the body more than clothing?
Look at the birds of the sky: they do not sow, they do not reap, and they do not gather into storehouses, yet your heavenly Father feeds them. Are you not worth much more than they are?
Which of you, by being anxious, is able to add a single cubit to his span of life?
And why are you anxious about clothing? Observe how the wildflowers of the field grow: they do not labor, and they do not spin.
Yet I tell you that not even Solomon in all his splendor was clothed like one of these.
Now if God so dresses the grass of the field, which is here today and thrown into the furnace tomorrow, will he not much more clothe you—you of little faith?
So do not be anxious, saying, 'What will we eat?' or 'What will we drink?' or 'What will we wear?'
For the nations chase after all these things, and your heavenly Father knows that you need them all.
But seek first his kingdom and his righteousness, and all these things will be given to you as well.
Therefore, do not be anxious about tomorrow, for tomorrow will be anxious for itself. Each day has enough trouble of its own."[/JESUS]

chapters.notes:
**"Performers" (v. 2, 5, 16)**: The Greek *hypokritai* refers to stage actors. In this context, it describes those whose religious life is a theatrical display intended for an audience rather than a sincere expression of devotion.

**"Received their payment in full" (v. 2, 5, 16)**: The verb *apechousin* was a technical term in the Greco-Roman business world used on receipts to indicate that a debt had been paid in full. The transaction is complete; they have no further claim to a reward from God.

**"Innermost room" (v. 6)**: The *tameion* was a private interior room, often a storage closet or treasury, and was the only room in a typical Palestinian house that could be locked from the inside.

**"Babble" / "Long-windedness" (v. 7)**: *Battalogēsēte* (babble) and *polylogia* (much-speaking) refer to the practice in pagan prayer of reciting long lists of divine names and formulas to "coerce" a deity into listening.

**"Bread we need for the coming day" (v. 11)**: The word *epiousion* is extremely rare. While traditionally "daily," it more likely derives from *hē epiousa* ("the coming day"). In an Aramaic-speaking context, this petitions God for the subsistence bread required for the immediate future.

**"Debts" (v. 12)**: In the Aramaic substrate of Jesus’s teaching, "debt" (*choba*) was a standard idiom for "sin." The Greek *opheilēmata* preserves this legal/financial metaphor for moral failure.

**"Time of trial" (v. 13)**: *Peirasmos* can mean temptation to sin, but in the context of Jewish apocalyptic thought and the Lord’s Prayer, it likely refers to the "great trial" or time of testing that precedes the establishment of God’s kingdom.

**"Sincere" vs. "Malicious" (v. 22-23)**: The Greek *haplous* (literally "single" or "simple") carries a secondary Jewish meaning of "generous." Conversely, the "evil eye" (*ponēros*) was a common Semitic idiom for stinginess, envy, or malice. The "lamp of the body" teaching is about one's moral lens and generosity.

**"Mammon" (v. 24)**: This is a transliteration of the Aramaic word for wealth or property. Jesus personifies it as a rival deity to emphasize that wealth exerts a "mastery" over the human heart.

**"Span of life" (v. 27)**: While *hēlikia* can mean physical height, a "cubit" (about 18 inches) was also used metaphorically to describe a measure of time. Since few people worry about being 18 inches taller, but many worry about living longer, "span of life" better captures the intent.

verses.text: [JESUS]"Do not sit in judgment, so that you will not be judged.
For with the verdict you pass, you will be judged, and by the standard you use to measure, it will be measured to you.
Why do you look at the speck of chaff in your brother’s eye, but you do not notice the great timber in your own eye?
Or how will you say to your brother, 'Let me take the speck out of your eye,' when—look!—the timber is in your own eye?
You performer! First take the timber out of your own eye, and then you will see clearly to take the speck out of your brother’s eye.
Do not give what is holy to the dogs, and do not throw your pearls before the pigs; otherwise, they will trample them under their feet and then turn and tear you to pieces.
Keep asking, and it will be given to you; keep seeking, and you will find; keep knocking, and the door will be opened for you.
For everyone who asks receives, and the one who seeks finds, and to the one who knocks, the door will be opened.
Or which of you, if his son asks for bread, will give him a stone?
Or if he asks for a fish—will he give him a snake?
So if you, though you are prone to evil, know how to give good gifts to your children, how much more will your Father in the heavens give good things to those who ask him!
In everything, therefore, treat people the way you want them to treat you; for this sums up the Law and the Prophets.
Enter through the narrow gate. For the gate is wide and the road is spacious that leads to destruction, and those entering through it are many.
But the gate is narrow and the road is cramped that leads to life, and those finding it are few.
Watch out for the false prophets, who come to you in sheep’s clothing but inwardly are ravenous wolves.
You will recognize them by their fruits. Are grapes gathered from thornbushes, or figs from thistles?
In the same way, every healthy tree produces fine fruit, but a diseased tree produces bad fruit.
A healthy tree cannot produce bad fruit, nor can a diseased tree produce fine fruit.
Every tree that does not produce fine fruit is cut down and thrown into the fire.
So then, you will recognize them by their fruits.
Not everyone who says to me, 'Lord, Lord,' will enter the kingdom of the heavens, but only the one who does the will of my Father in the heavens.
Many will say to me on that day, 'Lord, Lord, did we not prophesy in your name, and cast out demons in your name, and perform many acts of power in your name?'
And then I will declare to them, 'I never knew you; [SCRIPTURE]depart from me, you who practice lawlessness[/SCRIPTURE]!'
Therefore, everyone who hears these words of mine and acts on them will be like a sensible man who built his house on the rock.
The rain came down, the floods rose, and the winds blew and slammed against that house, but it did not collapse, because it had been founded on the rock.
And everyone who hears these words of mine and does not act on them will be like a foolish man who built his house on the sand.
The rain came down, the floods rose, and the winds blew and struck against that house, and it collapsed—and its collapse was total."[/JESUS]
And it happened that when Jesus had finished these words, the crowds were astounded at his teaching;
for he was teaching them as one who had authority, and not like their scholars of the Law.

chapters.notes:
**"Sit in judgment" (v. 1)**: The Greek *krinete* is broader than modern "judging" (forming an opinion). In this context, it carries the sense of passing a final verdict or acting as a judge over others' spiritual standing.

**"Speck of chaff" and "Timber" (v. 3-5)**: *Karphos* refers to a small bit of dried plant matter, like chaff or a splinter. *Dokon* refers to a massive wooden beam used in building construction. The translation uses "timber" to emphasize the absurdly large scale of the beam compared to the speck, which was a common Semitic hyperbole.

**"Performer" (v. 5)**: *Hypokrita* originally referred to a stage actor. Jesus is not just calling them inconsistent (the modern sense of "hypocrite"), but is critiquing their religious life as a theatrical display for an audience.

**"What is holy" (v. 6)**: *To hagion* likely refers to the "holy meat" of temple sacrifices. In a first-century Jewish context, giving sanctified meat to scavengers like dogs would be a profound desecration.

**"Prone to evil" (v. 11)**: *Ponēroi* ("evil" or "wicked"). Jesus uses this in a relative sense, contrasting human fallibility and the inherent self-interest of human nature with the perfect goodness of the heavenly Father.

**"Cramped" (v. 14)**: The Greek *tethlimmenē* comes from a root meaning "to compress" or "to squeeze." It suggests a path that is not only narrow but difficult and restrictive, involving pressure or tribulation.

**"Diseased" (v. 17-18)**: *Sapron* means rotten, decaying, or of poor quality. In the context of a tree, "diseased" or "rotten" captures the biological sense of why a tree produces "bad" (*ponērous*) fruit.

**"Acts of power" (v. 22)**: *Dynameis* is often translated as "miracles," but specifically refers to deeds that manifest divine power.

**"Lawlessness" (v. 23)**: *Anomian* literally means "being without law" or "violating the Law." In Matthew’s Gospel, this specifically refers to conduct that ignores the true intent of the Torah as interpreted by Jesus. The phrase is a quotation from Psalm 6:8.

**"Sensible" (v. 24)**: *Phronimō* refers to practical wisdom, prudence, or "street-smarts" in a spiritual sense—knowing how to act on information, not just possessing it.

**"Scholars of the Law" (v. 29)**: *Grammateis* (traditionally "scribes") were the professional class of experts in the interpretation and application of the Mosaic Law. "Scholars" better reflects their social and academic status.

verses.text: When he came down from the mountain, large crowds followed him.
Suddenly, a man with a serious skin disease approached and knelt in homage before him, saying, [SPEAKER:Leper]“Lord, if you are willing, you have the power to make me clean.”[/SPEAKER]
Extending his hand, Jesus touched him and said, [JESUS]“I am willing. Be made clean.”[/JESUS] Immediately his skin disease was cleansed.
Then Jesus said to him, [JESUS]“See that you tell no one; instead, go and show yourself to the priest and offer the gift that Moses commanded, as a testimony to them.”[/JESUS]
When Jesus entered Capernaum, a centurion approached him, pleading for help:
[SPEAKER:Centurion]“Lord, my servant lies at home paralyzed, suffering terribly.”[/SPEAKER]
Jesus said to him, [JESUS]“I will come and heal him.”[/JESUS]
But the centurion replied, [SPEAKER:Centurion]“Lord, I am not worthy for you to come under my roof; just say the word, and my servant will be healed.
For I too am a man under authority, with soldiers under me. I say to this one, ‘Go,’ and he goes; and to another, ‘Come,’ and he comes; and to my slave, ‘Do this,’ and he does it.”[/SPEAKER]
When Jesus heard this, he was amazed and said to those following him, [JESUS]“Truly I tell you, I have not found such faith as this with anyone in Israel.
I tell you that many will come from east and west and will recline at the banquet table with Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob in the kingdom of the heavens,
while the natural heirs of the kingdom will be thrown into the outer darkness; in that place, there will be weeping and grinding of teeth.”[/JESUS]
Then Jesus said to the centurion, [JESUS]“Go; let it be done for you just as you believed.”[/JESUS] And the servant was healed at that very moment.
When Jesus entered Peter’s house, he saw Peter’s mother-in-law lying in bed with a fever.
He touched her hand, and the fever left her; then she got up and began to serve him.
When evening came, they brought to him many who were possessed by demons; he drove out the spirits with a word and healed all who were ill.
This was to fulfill what was spoken through the prophet Isaiah, who said: [SCRIPTURE]“He himself took our infirmities and carried away our diseases.”[/SCRIPTURE]
Now when Jesus saw the large crowds surrounding him, he gave orders to depart for the other side of the Sea of Galilee.
A Torah scholar approached and said to him, [SPEAKER:Torah Scholar]“Teacher, I will follow you wherever you go.”[/SPEAKER]
Jesus said to him, [JESUS]“Foxes have dens and birds of the sky have nests, but the Son of Man has nowhere to lay his head.”[/JESUS]
Another of the disciples said to him, [SPEAKER:Disciple]“Lord, first let me go and bury my father.”[/SPEAKER]
But Jesus said to him, [JESUS]“Follow me, and let the dead bury their own dead.”[/JESUS]
As he stepped into the boat, his disciples followed him.
Without warning, a massive upheaval occurred in the sea, so that the boat was being engulfed by the waves; but Jesus was sleeping.
They went and woke him, saying, [SPEAKER:Disciples]“Lord, save us! We are perishing!”[/SPEAKER]
He said to them, [JESUS]“Why are you afraid, you of little faith?”[/JESUS] Then he got up and rebuked the winds and the sea, and a great calm followed.
The men were amazed and asked, [CROWD]“What kind of man is this, that even the winds and the sea obey him?”[/CROWD]
When he arrived at the other side, in the region of the Gadarenes, two demon-possessed men coming out of the tombs met him. They were so dangerously violent that no one could pass by that way.
Suddenly they shrieked, [SPEAKER:Demons]“What do you want with us, Son of God? Have you come here to torture us before the appointed time?”[/SPEAKER]
Now a large herd of pigs was feeding some distance from them.
The demons kept begging him, [SPEAKER:Demons]“If you drive us out, send us into the herd of pigs.”[/SPEAKER]
He said to them, [JESUS]“Go!”[/JESUS] So they came out and entered the pigs, and the entire herd rushed down the steep bank into the sea and perished in the waters.
The herdsmen fled, went into the town, and reported everything, including what had happened to the demon-possessed men.
Then the whole town came out to meet Jesus; and when they saw him, they pleaded with him to depart from their region.

chapters.notes:
**"Skin disease" (v. 2)**: The Greek *lepra* is traditionally "leprosy," but in the first century, it referred to a variety of scaling skin conditions (including psoriasis or infections) that rendered a person ritually unclean under Levitical law, not exclusively Hansen’s disease.

**"Knelt in homage" (v. 2)**: *Prosekunei* refers to the physical act of prostrating oneself or kneeling. In this context, it carries the weight of acknowledging Jesus’s superior authority, bordering on or expressing divine worship.

**"Servant" / "Boy" (v. 6)**: The Greek *pais* can mean "son" or "servant." In a military context, it often refers to a personal servant or armor-bearer for whom the officer feels a personal responsibility.

**"Recline at the banquet table" (v. 11)**: *Anaklithēsontai* literally means "to recline." This refers to the Middle Eastern custom of reclining on couches during a formal feast. It evokes the "Messianic Banquet" expected by Jews in the age to come.

**"Natural heirs of the kingdom" (v. 12)**: *Hoi hyioi tēs basileias* (literally "the sons of the kingdom") refers to those who, by covenant and lineage, expected to inherit the kingdom but are warned of exclusion due to lack of faith.

**"Torah scholar" (v. 19)**: *Grammateus* is traditionally "scribe." In this context, it refers to an expert in the interpretation and teaching of the Mosaic Law.

**"Son of Man" (v. 20)**: This is Jesus’s preferred self-designation, evoking the "one like a son of man" in Daniel 7:13-14, who is given everlasting dominion, while also emphasizing his shared humanity.

**"Let the dead bury their own dead" (v. 22)**: This is likely a hyperbolic Aramaic idiom. Jesus is not necessarily forbidding a funeral, but rather challenging the disciple to prioritize the immediate call of the kingdom over social and familial obligations, however sacred.

**"Massive upheaval" (v. 24)**: The Greek *seismos megas* usually means "great earthquake." Its use here for a storm at sea suggests a violent, earth-shaking disturbance of the elements.

**"What do you want with us" (v. 29)**: *Ti hēmin kai soi* is a Semitic idiom (Hebrew: *mah-lanu walak*) meaning "What is there to us and to you?" It functions as a way of saying, "Why are you interfering with us?" or "Leave us alone."

verses.text: And getting into a boat, he crossed over and came to his own city.
And behold, they were bringing to him a paralyzed man lying on a bed. When Jesus saw their faith, he said to the paralyzed man, [JESUS]“Take courage, child; your sins are released.”[/JESUS]
And behold, some of the scholars of the Law said among themselves, [SPEAKER:Scholars]“This man is blaspheming.”[/SPEAKER]
But Jesus, knowing their thoughts, said, [JESUS]“Why do you think such evil in your hearts?
For which is easier: to say, ‘Your sins are released,’ or to say, ‘Get up and walk’?
But so that you may know that the Son of Man has authority on the earth to release sins—”[/JESUS] then he said to the paralyzed man, [JESUS]“Get up, pick up your bed, and go to your home.”[/JESUS]
And he got up and went away to his home.
When the crowds saw it, they were struck with awe and glorified God, who had given such authority to human beings.
As Jesus passed on from there, he saw a man named Matthew sitting at the tax collector’s booth, and he said to him, [JESUS]“Follow me.”[/JESUS] And he stood up and followed him.
And it happened that as Jesus was reclining at the table in the house, behold, many tax collectors and “sinners” came and were reclining with Jesus and his disciples.
When the Pharisees saw this, they said to his disciples, [SPEAKER:Pharisees]“Why does your teacher eat with tax collectors and sinners?”[/SPEAKER]
But when he heard it, he said, [JESUS]“The healthy have no need of a physician, but those who are sick do.
But go and learn what this means: [SCRIPTURE]‘I desire mercy and not sacrifice.’[/SCRIPTURE] For I did not come to call the self-righteous, but sinners.”[/JESUS]
Then the disciples of John came to him, saying, [SPEAKER:Disciples of John]“Why do we and the Pharisees fast often, but your disciples do not fast?”[/SPEAKER]

Jesus said to them, [JESUS]“The wedding guests cannot mourn as long as the bridegroom is with them, can they? But the days will come when the bridegroom is taken away from them, and then they will fast.
No one puts a patch of unshrunk cloth on an old garment, for the patch pulls away from the garment, and the tear becomes worse.

Nor do people put new wine into old wineskins; otherwise, the skins burst, the wine spills out, and the skins are ruined. Instead, they put new wine into fresh wineskins, and both are preserved.”[/JESUS]

While he was saying these things to them, behold, a ruler came and bowed low before him, saying, [SPEAKER:Ruler]“My daughter has just now died; but come and lay your hand on her, and she will live.”[/SPEAKER]
Jesus got up and followed him, along with his disciples.
And behold, a woman who had suffered from a flow of blood for twelve years came up behind him and touched the ritual tassel of his cloak;
for she was saying to herself, [SPEAKER:Woman]“If I only touch his cloak, I will be restored to wholeness.”[/SPEAKER]
Jesus turned, and seeing her, he said, [JESUS]“Take courage, daughter; your faith has restored you.”[/JESUS] And the woman was restored to wholeness from that very hour.
When Jesus came to the ruler’s house and saw the flute players and the crowd in a mourning uproar,
he said, [JESUS]“Go away; for the girl has not died but is sleeping.”[/JESUS] And they began laughing at him.
But when the crowd had been sent outside, he went in and took her by the hand, and the girl was raised up.
And the report of this spread through that entire region.
As Jesus passed on from there, two blind men followed him, shouting out, [SPEAKER:Blind Men]“Have mercy on us, Son of David!”[/SPEAKER]

When he had entered the house, the blind men approached him, and Jesus said to them, [JESUS]“Do you believe that I am able to do this?”[/JESUS] They said to him, [SPEAKER:Blind Men]“Yes, Lord.”[/SPEAKER]
Then he touched their eyes, saying, [JESUS]“According to your faith, let it be done for you.”[/JESUS]
And their eyes were opened. And Jesus sternly warned them, [JESUS]“See that no one knows about this!”[/JESUS]
But they went out and spread his fame through 그 entire region.
As they were going out, behold, they brought to him a man who was unable to speak because he was demonized.
When the demon had been driven out, the man spoke. The crowds were amazed, saying, [CROWD]“Nothing like this has ever been seen in Israel!”[/CROWD]
But the Pharisees were saying, [SPEAKER:Pharisees]“He drives out demons by the ruler of the demons.”[/SPEAKER]
Jesus went through all the cities and the villages, teaching in their synagogues and preaching the good news of the Kingdom and healing every disease and every sickness.
When he saw the crowds, he was moved with deep compassion for them, because they were distressed and dejected, like sheep without a shepherd.
Then he said to his disciples, [JESUS]“The harvest is vast, but the workers are few.
Therefore, petition the Lord of the harvest to send out workers into his harvest.”[/JESUS]

chapters.notes:
**"His own city" (v. 1)**: Refers to Capernaum, which Jesus had made his headquarters (Matt 4:13) after leaving Nazareth.

**"Sins are released" (v. 2, 5)**: The Greek *aphiēmi* means to let go, dismiss, or cancel a debt. While "forgive" is the traditional religious term, "release" captures the Aramaic and Greek legal sense of being freed from the burden and penalty of sin.

**"Scholars of the Law" (v. 3)**: *Grammateis* (scribes) were the professional class of Torah experts and legalists.

**"Authority to human beings" (v. 8)**: The Greek *tois anthrōpois* is plural. While Jesus is the "Son of Man" (the unique human figure from Daniel 7), the crowd marvels that God has mediated this divine power to humanity.

**"Tax collector’s booth" (v. 9)**: The *telōnion* was a customs house. Matthew was likely a *telōnēs*, a contractor for Roman tax revenues, often viewed as a ritual outcast and a collaborator.

**"Self-righteous" (v. 13)**: The Greek *dikaioi* usually means "righteous," but in this polemical context against the Pharisees, Jesus is using the term ironically to refer to those who presume their own standing before God.

**"Wedding guests" (v. 15)**: The Greek *huioi tou nymphōnos* ("sons of the bridal chamber") is a Semitic idiom for the friends of the groom or wedding guests.

**"Ritual tassel" (v. 20)**: The *kraspedon* refers to the *tzitzit*, the ritual tassels required by the Law (Numbers 15:38) to be worn on the corners of a garment. This highlights the woman's reach for Jesus's identity as a Torah-observant Jew.

**"Restored to wholeness" (v. 21, 22)**: The Greek *sōzō* means "to save," but in medical contexts, it specifically refers to being healed or made whole. 

**"Mourning uproar" (v. 23)**: First-century Jewish funerals involved professional mourners and flute players (as mentioned here) to create a public display of grief.

**"Was raised up" (v. 25)**: The verb *ēgerthē* is the same word used for "resurrected." Matthew is signaling that this is more than just waking up; it is a foretaste of the resurrection.

**"Son of David" (v. 27)**: A specific Messianic title emphasizing the kingly lineage of the deliverer.

**"Sternly warned" (v. 30)**: The Greek *enebrimēthē* is a very strong word, sometimes used for the snorting of a horse. It implies a rigorous, even indignant charge.

**"Distressed and dejected" (v. 36)**: The Greek *eskyulmenoi* (literally "flayed/skinned") and *errimmenoi* (literally "thrown down/abandoned") paint a vivid picture of sheep that have been attacked and left for dead by negligent leaders.

**"Send out" (v. 38)**: The Greek *ekbalē* is a forceful verb, literally "to hurl out" or "drive out." It is the same word used for Jesus driving out demons. The workers are not just "sent" but "thrust" into the field.

verses.text: After summoning his twelve disciples, Jesus gave them authority over unclean spirits, so that they could drive them out and heal every kind of disease and every kind of infirmity.
Now these are the names of the twelve emissaries: first, Simon, who is called Peter, and Andrew his brother; James the son of Zebedee, and John his brother;
Philip and Bartholomew; Thomas and Matthew the tax collector; James the son of Alphaeus, and Thaddaeus;
Simon the Zealot, and Judas Iscariot, the one who handed him over.
These twelve Jesus sent out, after charging them with these instructions: [JESUS]“Do not go onto a road belonging to the Gentiles, and do not enter a city of the Samaritans.
Instead, go to the lost sheep of the house of Israel.
As you go, proclaim this message: ‘The Kingdom of the Heavens has drawn near.’
Heal the sick, raise the dead, cleanse those with skin diseases, drive out demons. You received as a gift; give as a gift.
Do not acquire gold or silver or copper for your money belts.
Take no traveling bag for the journey, nor an extra tunic, nor sandals, nor a staff; for the worker is worthy of his food.
Whatever city or village you enter, find out who in it is worthy, and stay there until you leave the area.
As you enter the house, give it your greeting of peace.
If the house is indeed worthy, let your peace come upon it; but if it is not worthy, let your peace return to you.
If anyone will not welcome you or listen to your words, as you leave that house or that city, shake the dust off your feet.
Truly I tell you, it will be more tolerable for the land of Sodom and Gomorrah on the day of judgment than for that city.
Look, I am sending you out like sheep in the midst of wolves. Therefore, be as shrewd as serpents and as innocent as doves.
But beware of people: for they will hand you over to local councils and scourge you in their synagogues.
You will even be brought before governors and kings for my sake, as a witness to them and to the nations.
But when they hand you over, do not worry about how or what you should speak; for what you should speak will be given to you in that hour.
For you are not the ones speaking, but the Spirit of your Father is the one speaking through you.
Brother will hand over brother to death, and a father his child; children will rise up against parents and have them put to death.
You will be hated by everyone because of my name. But the one who endures to the end—this person will be saved.
When they persecute you in one city, flee to the next. For truly I tell you, you will not have gone through all the cities of Israel before the Son of Man comes.
A disciple is not above the teacher, nor a slave above his master.

It is enough for the disciple to become like his teacher, and the slave like his master. If they have called the master of the house ‘Beelzebul,’ how much more will they malign the members of his household?
Therefore, do not fear them. For there is nothing covered up that will not be uncovered, and nothing hidden that will not be made known.
What I tell you in the darkness, speak in the light; and what you hear whispered in your ear, proclaim from the housetops.
Do not fear those who kill the body but are unable to kill the soul; rather, fear the one who is able to destroy both soul and body in Gehenna.
Are not two sparrows sold for an assarion? Yet not one of them will fall to the ground apart from your Father’s consent.
Even the hairs of your head are all numbered.
So do not be afraid; you are worth more than many sparrows.
Everyone, therefore, who acknowledges me before others, I also will acknowledge before my Father who is in the heavens.
But whoever denies me before others, I also will deny before my Father who is in the heavens.
Do not suppose that I came to bring peace to the earth; I did not come to bring peace, but a sword.
For I came [SCRIPTURE]‘to set a man against his father, and a daughter against her mother, and a daughter-in-law against her mother-in-law;
and a man’s enemies will be the members of his own household.’[/SCRIPTURE]
The one who loves father or mother more than me is not worthy of me; and the one who loves son or daughter more than me is not worthy of me.
Whoever does not take up his cross and follow after me is not worthy of me.
The one who finds his life will lose it, and the one who loses his life for my sake will find it.
The one who receives you receives me, and the one who receives me receives the one who sent me.

The one who receives a prophet because he is a prophet will receive a prophet’s reward; and the one who receives a righteous person because he is a righteous person will receive a righteous person’s reward.
And whoever gives even a cup of cold water to one of these little ones because he is a disciple—truly I tell you, he will certainly not lose his reward.”[/JESUS]

chapters.notes:
**Emissaries (v. 2)**: The Greek *apostoloi* refers to authorized messengers or agents sent with the authority of the sender. While "apostle" is the traditional transliteration, "emissary" or "authorized agent" captures the functional legal nuance of the *shaliach* in Jewish tradition.

**Handed him over (v. 4, 17, 19, 21)**: The verb *paradidōmi* is used consistently for Judas’s action against Jesus and the persecution of the disciples. Using "handed over" instead of "betrayed" preserves the author's intentional linguistic connection between the fate of the Master and the fate of the disciples.

**Zealot (v. 4)**: The Greek *Kananaios* is a transliteration of the Aramaic *qan’ana*, which means "zealot." It likely refers to Simon’s political or religious faction rather than his geographic origin (Cana).

**Kingdom of the Heavens (v. 7)**: This reflects Matthew’s consistent use of the plural *ouranoi* and the Jewish practice of using "the Heavens" as a metonym for God to avoid speaking the divine name directly.

**Innocent (v. 16)**: The Greek *akeraioi* literally means "unmixed" or "pure." In this context, it suggests a simplicity of motive or lack of guile, contrasting with the shrewdness of the serpent.

**Local councils (v. 17)**: The Greek *synedria* (Sanhedrins) refers to local Jewish judicial bodies, not necessarily the Great Sanhedrin in Jerusalem.

**Beelzebul (v. 25)**: Likely derived from the Philistine "Baal-Zebub" (Lord of the Flies) or the Hebrew "Baal-Zebul" (Lord of the Prince/Manor/Dung). It was a contemporary epithet for the prince of demons.

**Soul (v. 28, 39)**: The Greek *psychē* corresponds to the Hebrew *nephesh*, meaning the whole person, the life-force, or the essential self. The English "soul" often carries a dualistic Greek philosophical weight, but here it refers to the life that God sustains beyond physical death.

**Gehenna (v. 28)**: A reference to the Valley of Hinnom (*Ge Hinnom*) outside Jerusalem, which served as a historical site of child sacrifice and later a refuse dump. It was the standard 1st-century Jewish metaphor for the place of final judgment.

**Assarion (v. 29)**: A specific small Roman copper coin worth 1/16th of a denarius. Retaining the specific term emphasizes the insignificance of the price.

**Acknowledges me (v. 32)**: The Greek *homologeō en emoi* follows a Semitic idiom (confess *in* me), implying a public declaration of allegiance or a union of identity.

**Take up his cross (v. 38)**: To a first-century audience, the *stauros* (cross) was not a religious symbol but a terrifying instrument of state execution and public humiliation used by Rome to crush insurrection. Jesus is using a metaphor for total submission to a path that leads to death.

**Because he is (v. 41-42)**: The Greek phrase *eis onoma* (literally "into the name of") is a Semitic idiom meaning "for the sake of," "by reason of," or "in the capacity of." It indicates that the person is being received specifically because of their role as a prophet, righteous person, or disciple.

verses.text: And it happened that when Jesus had finished giving instructions to his twelve disciples, he departed from there to teach and herald his message in their cities.
Now when John heard in prison about the works of the Christ, he sent word through his disciples
and said to him, [SPEAKER:John's Disciples]“Are you ‘The Coming One,’ or should we look for someone else?”[/SPEAKER]
And Jesus answered them, [JESUS]“Go and report to John what you are hearing and seeing:
the blind see again and the lame walk, lepers are cleansed and the deaf hear, the dead are raised and the poor are told the good news.
And a blessing rests on anyone who does not stumble because of me.”[/JESUS]
As these men were leaving, Jesus began to speak to the crowds about John: [JESUS]“What did you go out into the wilderness to gaze at? A reed shaken by the wind?
Really, what did you go out to see? A man dressed in soft, expensive robes? Look, those who wear soft clothes are found in the palaces of kings.
But why did you go out? To see a prophet? Yes, I tell you, and someone much greater than a prophet.
This is the one about whom it stands written: [SCRIPTURE]‘Look, I am sending my messenger ahead of you, who will prepare your way before you.’[/SCRIPTURE]
Truly I tell you, among those born of women there has not arisen anyone greater than John the Baptizer; yet the one who is least in the kingdom of the heavens is greater than he.
From the days of John the Baptizer until now, the kingdom of the heavens has been breaking through with force, and violent men try to seize it.
For all the Prophets and the Law prophesied until John came.
And if you are willing to accept it, he is Elijah, the one who was destined to come.
Let the one who has ears listen!
To what, then, shall I compare this generation? It is like children sitting in the marketplaces who call out to their playmates,
saying, [CROWD]‘We played the flute for you, and you didn't dance; we sang a funeral dirge, and you didn't beat your chests in grief.’[/CROWD]
For John came neither eating nor drinking, and they say, ‘He has a demon!’
The Son of Man came eating and drinking, and they say, ‘Look! A glutton and a drunkard, a friend of tax collectors and sinners!’ Yet Wisdom is vindicated by her works.”[/JESUS]
Then he began to reproach the cities in which most of his acts of power had been done, because they did not repent:
[JESUS]“Woe to you, Chorazin! Woe to you, Bethsaida! For if the acts of power done in you had been done in Tyre and Sidon, they would have repented long ago in sackcloth and ashes.
Nevertheless I tell you, it will be more bearable for Tyre and Sidon on the day of judgment than for you.
And you, Capernaum, will you be ‘exalted to heaven’? You will go down to Hades! For if the acts of power done in you had been done in Sodom, it would have remained until this very day.
Nevertheless I tell you that it will be more bearable for the land of Sodom on the day of judgment than for you.”[/JESUS]

At that time, Jesus spoke up and said, [JESUS]“I give you public praise, Father, Lord of heaven and earth, because you have hidden these things from the ‘wise and learned’ and revealed them to little children.
Yes, Father, for this was well-pleasing in your sight.

All things have been handed over to me by my Father, and no one truly knows the Son except the Father, nor does anyone truly know the Father except the Son and anyone to whom the Son chooses to reveal him.
Come to me, all you who are weary and carrying heavy burdens, and I will give you rest.
Take my yoke upon you and learn from me, for I am gentle and humble in heart, and you will find rest for your souls.
For my yoke is easy to bear, and my burden is light.”[/JESUS]

chapters.notes:
**"The Christ" (v. 2)**: The Greek *tou christou* includes the definite article, signaling it as a title ("The Messiah") rather than a proper name. John is questioning if Jesus is fulfilling the specific office he expected.

**"The Coming One" (v. 3)**: *Ho erchomenos* was a contemporary Messianic title based on passages like Psalm 118:26 and Habakkuk 2:3.

**"Stumble" (v. 6)**: *Skandalisthe* refers to the *skandalon*, the trigger of a trap. It describes someone being tripped up or falling away because Jesus did not fit their expectations of the Messiah (e.g., John being in prison while the "Coming One" is present).

**"Breaking through with force" (v. 12)**: The Greek *biazetai* is notoriously difficult. It can be passive ("is being treated violently") or middle ("is forcing its way forward"). Given the context of John’s imprisonment and the Aramaic substratum (*perats*), it likely refers to the Kingdom's dynamic, forceful entry into the world which provokes a violent reaction from "violent men" (*biastai*).

**"Wisdom is vindicated by her works" (v. 19)**: Some manuscripts read "children" (*teknōn*), but the SBLGNT follows the earlier "works" (*ergōn*). This creates a literary frame with verse 2, where John hears of the "works" of the Christ. Wisdom’s "works" are the deeds of Jesus and John, regardless of the generation's criticism.

**"Acts of power" (v. 20, 21, 23)**: *Dunameis* is often translated as "miracles," but it literally means "powers" or "mighty deeds." To the original audience, these weren't just wonders to behold, but outbursts of the power of the coming Kingdom.

**"Hades" (v. 23)**: Retained as a loanword. In the Septuagint, it corresponds to *Sheol*, the realm of the dead. It stands in contrast to the height of "heaven."

**"Public praise" (v. 25)**: *Exomologoumai* means more than a private "thank you." It is a grateful, public acknowledgment of God's sovereignty.

**"Easy to bear" (v. 30)**: The Greek *chrēstos* can mean "kind," "good," or "well-fitting." In the context of a yoke, it suggests a harness that does not chafe the neck—one that is shaped perfectly for the wearer.

verses.text: Around 그 time, Jesus walked through the grainfields on the Sabbath. His disciples were hungry and began to pluck heads of grain and eat them.
When the Pharisees saw this, they said to him, [SPEAKER:Pharisees]“Look! Your disciples are doing what is not permitted to do on the Sabbath.”[/SPEAKER]
But he said to them, [JESUS]“Have you not read what David did when he and those with him were hungry?
How he entered the house of God and they ate the Bread of the Presence, which was not permitted for him or those with him to eat, but only for the priests?
Or have you not read in the Law that on the Sabbath the priests in the temple profane the Sabbath and yet are guiltless?
I tell you that something greater than the temple is here.
If you had known what this means, [SCRIPTURE]‘I desire mercy and not sacrifice,’[/SCRIPTURE] you would not have condemned the guiltless.
For the Son of Man is Lord of the Sabbath.”[/JESUS]
Moving on from there, he went into their synagogue.
And look, there was a man with a withered hand. To find an accusation against Jesus, they questioned him, [SPEAKER:Pharisees]“Is it permitted to heal on the Sabbath?”[/SPEAKER]
He said to them, [JESUS]“Which of you, if you had one sheep and it fell into a pit on the Sabbath, would not take hold of it and lift it out?
How much more valuable, then, is a human being than a sheep! So then, it is permitted to do good on the Sabbath.”[/JESUS]
Then he said to the man, [JESUS]“Stretch out your hand.”[/JESUS] He stretched it out, and it was restored to health, just like the other one.
But the Pharisees went out and conspired against him, plotting how they might destroy him.
Aware of this, Jesus withdrew from there. Many followed him, and he healed them all,
but he warned them not to make him known.
This was to fulfill what was spoken through Isaiah the prophet:
[SCRIPTURE]“Look! My servant whom I have chosen, my beloved in whom my soul delights. I will put my Spirit upon him, and he will proclaim justice to the nations.
He will not wrangle or cry out, nor will anyone hear his voice in the wide streets.
A bruised reed he will not snap, and a smoldering wick he will not extinguish, until he leads justice to victory.
And in his name the nations will put their hope.”[/SCRIPTURE]
Then a demon-possessed man who was blind and mute was brought to him. Jesus healed him, so that the man could both speak and see.
All the crowds were amazed and began to say, [CROWD]“Could this be the Son of David?”[/CROWD]
But when the Pharisees heard it, they said, [SPEAKER:Pharisees]“This man casts out demons only by Beelzebul, the ruler of the demons.”[/SPEAKER]
Knowing their inner deliberations, he said to them, [JESUS]“Every kingdom divided against itself is brought to ruin, and every city or house divided against itself will not stand.
If Satan casts out Satan, he is divided against himself; how then will his kingdom stand?
And if I cast out demons by Beelzebul, by whom do your sons cast them out? For this reason, they will be your judges.
But if I cast out demons by the Spirit of God, then the kingdom of God has overtaken you.
Or how can anyone enter the strong man’s house and snatch his possessions unless he first binds the strong man? Only then can he plunder his house.
Whoever is not with me is against me, and whoever does not gather with me scatters.
Therefore I tell you, every sin and slanderous speech will be forgiven people, but the defamation of the Spirit will not be forgiven.
Whoever speaks a word against the Son of Man will be forgiven, but whoever speaks against the Holy Spirit will not be forgiven, either in this age or in the age to come.
Either make the tree good and its fruit good, or make the tree rotten and its fruit rotten; for the tree is known by its fruit.
Offspring of vipers! How can you, being evil, say anything good? For the mouth speaks out of the heart's overflow.
The good person brings good things out of a good treasure-store, and the evil person brings evil things out of an evil treasure-store.
I tell you that for every idle word people speak, they will give an account on the day of judgment.
For by your words you will be justified, and by your words you will be condemned.”[/JESUS]
Then some of the scribes and Pharisees answered him, [SPEAKER:Scribes and Pharisees]“Teacher, we want to see a sign from you.”[/SPEAKER]
He answered them, [JESUS]“An evil and unfaithful generation demands a sign, but no sign will be given to it except the sign of the prophet Jonah.
For just as Jonah was in the belly of the sea monster for three days and three nights, so the Son of Man will be in the heart of the earth for three days and three nights.
The men of Nineveh will stand up at the judgment with this generation and condemn it, because they repented at the preaching of Jonah—and look, something greater than Jonah is here!

The Queen of the South will be raised up at the judgment with this generation and condemn it, because she came from the ends of the earth to hear the wisdom of Solomon—and look, something greater than Solomon is here!
When an unclean spirit comes out of a person, it wanders through waterless places seeking rest and does not find it.
Then it says, ‘I will return to my house from which I came.’ Upon arriving, it finds the house unoccupied, swept clean, and put in order.

Then it goes and brings along seven other spirits more evil than itself, and they enter and settle there. And the final state of that person becomes worse than the first. So it will be also with this evil generation.”[/JESUS]
While he was still speaking to the crowds, look, his mother and brothers stood outside, seeking to speak to him.
But he replied to the one who told him, [JESUS]“Who is my mother, and who are my brothers?”[/JESUS]
And stretching out his hand toward his disciples, he said, [JESUS]“Look! Here are my mother and my brothers.
For whoever does the will of my Father in heaven is my brother and sister and mother.”[/JESUS]

chapters.notes:
**Something greater than the temple** (v. 6): The Greek *meizon* is neuter, not masculine. Jesus is not simply saying "I am greater than the temple," but that something about the situation—the arrival of the Kingdom and his messianic presence—surpasses the temple institution. This is repeated in verses 41 and 42 regarding Jonah and Solomon.

**Mercy and not sacrifice** (v. 7): A direct quote of Hosea 6:6. In the Hebrew context, this is a comparative idiom (dialectical negation) meaning "mercy rather than mere ritual."

**Son of Man** (v. 8): Jesus' preferred self-designation, evoking the "one like a son of man" in Daniel 7:13-14 who is given everlasting dominion by the Ancient of Days.

**Withered hand** (v. 10): The Greek *xēran* (dry/wasted) suggests a limb that was atrophied or paralyzed, making it a permanent disability rather than an acute injury.

**Justice** (v. 18, 20): The Greek *krisin* refers to the Hebrew *mishpat*—not just legal sentencing, but the establishment of God's right order and justice in the world.

**Beelzebul** (v. 24): Likely derived from *Baal-Zebub* (Lord of the Flies) or *Baal-Zebul* (Lord of the Manor/Prince Baal). By Jesus' time, it was a popular name for the prince of demons.

**Defamation of the Spirit** (v. 31): The Greek *blasphēmia* refers to slander or speaking impiously. In this context, it is the specific act of attributing the clear work of the Holy Spirit (healing and deliverance) to the power of the devil.

**Idle word** (v. 36): *Argon* literally means "not working" or "unproductive." It refers to words that are careless, useless, or fail to accomplish the good they ought to.

**Unfaithful generation** (v. 39): *Moichalis* literally means "adulterous," but in the context of the Hebrew prophets, spiritual adultery referred to covenant unfaithfulness toward God.

**Sea monster** (v. 40): The Greek *kētos* refers to any large sea creature or monster, not specifically a whale.

**Unoccupied** (v. 44): *Scholazonta* (from which we get "school") means "at leisure" or "empty." The house is clean but lacks a new master (the Spirit), leaving it vulnerable.

**Verse 47**: This verse ("Someone told him, 'Look, your mother and brothers are standing outside, wanting to speak to you'") is omitted because it is absent from several of the most important early manuscripts (including Sinaiticus and Vaticanus) and is likely a later harmonization from Mark 3:32 or Luke 8:20.

verses.text: On that same day, Jesus left the house and sat down by the sea.
Such massive crowds gathered around him that he stepped into a boat and sat there, while the entire crowd stood on the shore.
He spoke many things to them in parables, saying: [JESUS]"Listen! A sower went out to sow.
As he sowed, some seeds fell along the path, and the birds came and devoured them.
Others fell on rocky ground where they did not have much soil; they sprang up quickly because the soil had no depth.
But when the sun rose, they were scorched, and because they had no root, they withered away.
Others fell among the thorns, and the thorns grew up and choked them.
But others fell on the good soil and produced a crop—some a hundred times what was sown, some sixty, and some thirty.
Let the person who has ears listen!"[/JESUS]
Then the disciples came and asked him, [SPEAKER:Disciples]"Why do you speak to them in parables?"[/SPEAKER]
He answered them, [JESUS]"Because to you it has been granted to know the secrets of the Kingdom of the Heavens, but to them it has not been granted.
For whoever has, more will be given to him and he will have an abundance; but whoever does not have, even what he has will be taken away from him.
This is why I speak to them in parables: because beholding they do not see, and hearing they do not hear, nor do they understand.
In them is fulfilled the prophecy of Isaiah which says: [SCRIPTURE]'You will indeed hear but never understand, and you will indeed look but never perceive.

For this people’s heart has become calloused; they have grown hard of hearing with their ears, and they have shut their eyes tightly—otherwise they might see with their eyes and hear with their ears and understand with their heart and turn back, and I would heal them.'[/SCRIPTURE]
But blessed are your eyes because they see, and your ears because they hear.
Truly I tell you, many prophets and righteous people longed to see what you see and did not see it, and to hear what you hear and did not hear it.
You, then, listen to the parable of the sower.
When anyone hears the word of the Kingdom and does not understand it, the evil one comes and snatches away what was sown in his heart; this is the one sown along the path.
As for the one sown on the rocky ground, this is the one who hears the word and immediately receives it with joy,
