yet he has no root in himself but lasts only a short time; when hardship or persecution comes because of the word, he is immediately tripped up.
As for the one sown among the thorns, this is the one who hears the word, but the anxiety of this age and the seductive deception of wealth choke the word, and it becomes unfruitful.
But as for the one sown on the good soil, this is the one who hears the word and understands it; he indeed bears fruit and produces—one a hundredfold, another sixty, and another thirty."[/JESUS]
He presented another parable to them, saying: [JESUS]"The Kingdom of the Heavens may be compared to a man who sowed good seed in his field.
But while everyone was sleeping, his enemy came and sowed weeds among the wheat and slipped away.
When the stalks sprouted and produced grain, then the weeds appeared as well.
The slaves of the master of the house came and said to him, [SPEAKER:Slaves]'Master, didn't you sow good seed in your field? Where did these weeds come from?'[/SPEAKER]
He said to them, [JESUS]'An enemy has done this.'[/JESUS] The slaves said to him, [SPEAKER:Slaves]'Then do you want us to go and gather them up?'[/SPEAKER]
But he said, [JESUS]'No, for in gathering the weeds you might uproot the wheat along with them.

Let both grow together until the harvest; and at harvest time I will tell the harvesters: "First gather the weeds and bind them into bundles to be burned, but bring the wheat into my barn."'"[/JESUS][/JESUS]
He presented another parable to them, saying: [JESUS]"The Kingdom of the Heavens is like a mustard seed that a man took and sowed in his field.
It is the smallest of all seeds, but when it has grown, it is the largest of the garden plants and becomes a tree, so that the birds of the sky come and nest in its branches."[/JESUS]
He spoke another parable to them: [JESUS]"The Kingdom of the Heavens is like leaven that a woman took and hid in three large measures of flour until it was all leavened."[/JESUS]
Jesus spoke all these things to the crowds in parables; indeed, he said nothing to them without a parable.
This was to fulfill what was spoken through the prophet, saying: [SCRIPTURE]"I will open my mouth in parables; I will pour out things hidden since the foundation of the world."[/SCRIPTURE]
Then, leaving the crowds, he went into the house. His disciples came to him and said, [SPEAKER:Disciples]"Explain to us the parable of the weeds in the field."[/SPEAKER]
He answered, [JESUS]"The one who sows the good seed is the Son of Man.
The field is the world, and the good seed—these are the sons of the Kingdom. The weeds are the sons of the evil one,
and the enemy who sowed them is the devil. The harvest is the completion of the age, and the harvesters are angels.
Just as the weeds are gathered and burned with fire, so it will be at the completion of the age.
The Son of Man will send his angels, and they will gather out of his Kingdom all the causes of sin and those who practice lawlessness,
and they will throw them into the fiery furnace; in that place there will be weeping and gnashing of teeth.
Then the righteous will shine like the sun in the Kingdom of their Father. Let the person who has ears listen!
The Kingdom of the Heavens is like treasure hidden in a field, which a man found and covered up. Then in his joy, he goes and sells everything he has and buys that field.
Again, the Kingdom of the Heavens is like a merchant searching for fine pearls.
Finding one pearl of great value, he went and sold everything he had and bought it.
Again, the Kingdom of the Heavens is like a dragnet thrown into the sea that caught fish of every kind.
When it was full, they hauled it up onto the shore; then they sat down and sorted the good fish into containers, but threw the rotten ones away.
So it will be at the completion of the age. The angels will go out and separate the evil from the midst of the righteous
and throw them into the fiery furnace; in that place there will be weeping and gnashing of teeth.
Have you understood all these things?"[/JESUS] They said to him, [CROWD]"Yes."[/CROWD]

He said to them, [JESUS]"Therefore, every scholar of the Law who has been discipled for the Kingdom of the Heavens is like a master of a house who brings out of his storeroom things both new and old."[/JESUS]
When Jesus had finished these parables, he moved on from there.
He came to his hometown and began teaching the people in their synagogue, so that they were astonished and said, [CROWD]"Where did this man get this wisdom and these miracles?
Isn't this the builder’s son? Isn't his mother named Mary, and aren't his brothers James, Joseph, Simon, and Judas?
And aren't all his sisters right here with us? Where did he get all this?"[/CROWD]
And they were tripped up by him. But Jesus said to them, [JESUS]"A prophet is not without honor except in his hometown and in his own household."[/JESUS]
And he did not perform many miracles there because of their lack of trust.

chapters.notes:
**"Kingdom of the Heavens" (v. 11, etc.)**: This is a literal rendering of the Greek *basileia tōn ouranōn*. Matthew consistently uses "heavens" (plural) as a Semitic circumlocution to avoid direct use of the divine name, reflecting the Jewish context of his audience.

**"Secrets" (v. 11)**: The Greek *mystēria* refers to things previously hidden but now being revealed to an "in-group." "Secrets" or "mysteries" captures this better than "doctrines."

**"Beholding they do not see" (v. 13)**: This reflects a Semitic idiom (the infinitive absolute) used for emphasis. The repetition conveys a state of persistent, willful blindness.

**"Tripped up" (v. 21, 57)**: The Greek *skandalizetai* (v. 21) and *eskandalizonto* (v. 57) imply being "snared" or "caused to stumble." In v. 21, it describes someone losing their footing in faith due to pressure. In v. 57, it describes the townsfolk's inability to accept Jesus because of their familiarity with him; he became a "stumbling block" to them.

**"Seductive deception of wealth" (v. 22)**: The Greek *apatē* carries the nuance of a "lure" or "trickery." It’s not just the presence of wealth, but the way it deceives a person into a false sense of security.

**"Weeds" (v. 25)**: The Greek *zizania* likely refers to "darnel" (*Lolium temulentum*), a toxic weed that looks nearly identical to wheat until it matures. This botanical reality is essential to the parable's logic: the servants cannot distinguish them early on.

**"Completion of the age" (v. 39, 40, 49)**: The Greek *synteleia aiōnos* refers to the climax or consummation of the current era, rather than the destruction of the physical "world" (*kosmos*).

**"Causes of sin" (v. 41)**: *Skandala* here refers to things (or people) that cause others to fall away or stumble.

**"Scholar of the Law" (v. 52)**: *Grammateus* (traditionally "scribe") refers to an expert in the interpretation of the Hebrew Scriptures. In this context, Jesus refers to a scholar who now interprets the Law through the lens of the Kingdom.

**"Builder" (v. 55)**: The Greek *tektōn* refers to a craftsman or artisan who works with hard materials like wood, stone, or metal. While traditionally "carpenter," "builder" or "artisan" better reflects the diverse construction skills required in first-century Galilee.

**"Lack of trust" (v. 58)**: The Greek *apistia* is often translated "unbelief," but in this context, it refers to a relational lack of trust or confidence in Jesus's person and authority.

verses.text: At that season, Herod the tetrarch heard the reports about Jesus,
and he said to his attendants, [SPEAKER:Herod]“This is John the Baptist; he has been raised from the dead, and that is why these miraculous powers are at work in him.”[/SPEAKER]
For Herod had arrested John, bound him, and put him in prison on account of Herodias, the wife of his brother Philip.
This was because John had been telling him, [SPEAKER:John]“It is not lawful for you to have her.”[/SPEAKER]
Although Herod wanted to kill him, he feared the crowd because they regarded John as a prophet.
But when Herod’s birthday came, the daughter of Herodias danced before the company and delighted Herod.
Consequently, he promised with an oath to give her whatever she might ask.
Prompted by her mother, she said, [SPEAKER:Herodias's Daughter]“Give me here on a large platter the head of John the Baptist.”[/SPEAKER]
And though the king was grieved, because of his oaths and the dinner guests, he commanded it to be given.
He sent and had John beheaded in the prison.
His head was brought on a platter and given to the girl, and she brought it to her mother.
Then his disciples came and took the corpse and buried it; and they went and told Jesus.
When Jesus heard this, he withdrew from there in a boat to a wilderness place to be alone. But when the crowds heard of it, they followed him on foot from the towns.
When he went ashore, he saw a vast crowd, and he was moved with a compassion that stirred his very core for them, and he healed those among them who were sick.

When evening came, the disciples approached him and said, [SPEAKER:Disciples]“This is a wilderness place and the hour is already late; dismiss the crowds so that they can go into the villages and buy food for themselves.”[/SPEAKER]
But Jesus said to them, [JESUS]“They have no need to go away; you give them something to eat.”[/JESUS]
They said to him, [SPEAKER:Disciples]“We have nothing here except five loaves of bread and two fish.”[/SPEAKER]
He said, [JESUS]“Bring them here to me.”[/JESUS]

Then he directed the crowds to sit down on the grass. Taking the five loaves and the two fish, he looked up toward heaven and spoke a blessing; then he broke the loaves and gave them to the disciples, and the disciples gave them to the crowds.
And they all ate and were completely satisfied. They picked up twelve full wicker baskets of the broken pieces that were left over.
Those who ate were about five thousand men, besides women and children.
Immediately he compelled the disciples to get into the boat and go ahead of him to the other side, while he dismissed the crowds.
After he had dismissed the crowds, he went up on the mountain by himself to pray. When evening came, he was there alone.
But the boat was already many hundreds of yards from the land, being battered by the waves, for the wind was against them.
And in the fourth watch of the night, he came toward them walking on the sea.
When the disciples saw him walking on the sea, they were terrified, saying, [SPEAKER:Disciples]“It is a ghost!”[/SPEAKER] and they cried out in fear.
But immediately Jesus spoke to them, saying, [JESUS]“Take courage, I am; do not be afraid.”[/JESUS]
Peter answered him, [SPEAKER:Peter]“Lord, if it is you, command me to come to you on the waters.”[/SPEAKER]
He said, [JESUS]“Come.”[/JESUS] So Peter got out of the boat, walked on the waters, and came toward Jesus.
But when he saw the strong wind, he became afraid, and beginning to sink, he cried out, [SPEAKER:Peter]“Lord, save me!”[/SPEAKER]
Immediately Jesus reached out his hand and took hold of him, saying to him, [JESUS]“You of little faith, why did you waver?”[/JESUS]
When they got into the boat, the wind died down.
Then those in the boat worshiped him, saying, [SPEAKER:Disciples]“Truly you are the Son of God.”[/SPEAKER]
When they had crossed over, they came to land at Gennesaret.
After the men of that place recognized him, they sent word into all that surrounding region and brought to him all who were sick.
They kept begging him that they might only touch the tassel of his garment, and as many as touched it were restored to health.

chapters.notes:
**"Tetrarch" (v. 1)**: This technical term for a ruler of a fourth part of a region is retained to reflect the political reality of the Herodian dynasty under Roman oversight.

**"Miraculous powers" (v. 2)**: The Greek *hai dynameis* literally means "the powers." In this context, it refers specifically to the inherent supernatural capacities or "energies" that enable miracles.

**"Moved with a compassion that stirred his very core" (v. 14)**: The verb *esplanchnisthē* is derived from the word for internal organs (*splangchna*). To a first-century reader, this indicated a visceral, physical reaction of pity located in the gut, rather than a purely intellectual or sentimental feeling.

**"Spoke a blessing" (v. 19)**: The Greek *eulogēsen* reflects the Jewish *berakhah*. Jesus isn't "blessing the bread" in a modern sense, but rather "blessing God" for the bread, as was the standard practice before a meal.

**"Completely satisfied" (v. 20)**: The Greek *echortasthēsan* was originally used for fattening animals with fodder. In the NT, it implies being filled to the point of total satiation.

**"I am" (v. 27)**: While *egō eimi* is a standard way to say "It’s me," it also deliberately echoes the divine self-identification of Yahweh in the Septuagint (Exodus 3:14). Given the context of Jesus walking on water—a prerogative attributed to God in the Hebrew Scriptures (Job 9:8)—the dual meaning is intended.

**"Waver" (v. 31)**: The Greek *edistasas* comes from a root meaning "double-standing." It depicts the internal state of being divided between two opinions or directions, rather than a simple lack of belief.

**"Tassel" (v. 36)**: The *kraspedon* refers to the ritual fringes or tassels (*tzitzit*) that Jewish men were required to wear on the corners of their garments (Numbers 15:38–39). This highlights Jesus’s identity as a Torah-observant Jew and may evoke the prophecy of Malachi 4:2 regarding "healing in his wings/corners."

verses.text: Then Pharisees and legal experts from Jerusalem approach Jesus, saying,
[SPEAKER:Pharisees and Scribes]"Why do your disciples violate the tradition of the elders? For they do not ritually wash their hands whenever they eat a meal."[/SPEAKER]
But he replied to them, [JESUS]"And why do you violate the commandment of God for the sake of your tradition?
For God said, [SCRIPTURE]‘Honor your father and your mother,’[/SCRIPTURE] and, [SCRIPTURE]‘The one who speaks evil of father or mother must surely be put to death.’[/SCRIPTURE]
But you say, ‘Whoever says to his father or his mother, “Whatever support you might have received from me is a dedicated gift to God,”’
he is then not to honor his father. Thus you have nullified the word of God for the sake of your tradition.
You performers! Isaiah prophesied correctly about you when he said:
[SCRIPTURE]‘This people honors me with their lips, but their heart is far away from me;
they worship me in vain, teaching as doctrines the mere regulations of men.’[/SCRIPTURE]"[/JESUS]
And having called the crowd to him, he said to them, [JESUS]"Listen and understand:
it is not what enters the mouth that profanes a person; rather, what comes out of the mouth—this is what profanes a person."[/JESUS]
Then the disciples came and said to him, [SPEAKER:Disciples]"Do you know that the Pharisees were scandalized when they heard this teaching?"[/SPEAKER]
But he answered, [JESUS]"Every plant that my heavenly Father did not plant will be uprooted.
Leave them alone; they are blind guides of the blind. And if a blind person guides a blind person, both will fall into a pit."[/JESUS]
Peter responded to him, [SPEAKER:Peter]"Explain this parable to us."[/SPEAKER]
He said, [JESUS]"Are you still without understanding?
Do you not realize that everything entering the mouth passes into the stomach and is discharged into the latrine?
But the things that come out of the mouth originate from the heart, and those are what profane a person.
For out of the heart come wicked schemes, murders, adulteries, sexual immoralities, thefts, false testimonies, and slanders.
These are the things that profane a person; but to eat with unwashed hands does not profane a person."[/JESUS]
And leaving that place, Jesus withdrew to the regions of Tyre and Sidon.
And look, a Canaanite woman from those districts came out and began crying out, [SPEAKER:Canaanite Woman]"Have mercy on me, Lord, Son of David! My daughter is severely demon-possessed."[/SPEAKER]
But he did not answer her a word. And his disciples approached and urged him, saying, [SPEAKER:Disciples]"Send her away, for she keeps crying out after us."[/SPEAKER]
But he answered, [JESUS]"I was sent only to the lost sheep of the house of Israel."[/JESUS]
But she came and knelt before him, saying, [SPEAKER:Canaanite Woman]"Lord, help me!"[/SPEAKER]
He answered, [JESUS]"It is not right to take the children’s bread and throw it to the little dogs."[/JESUS]
But she said, [SPEAKER:Canaanite Woman]"Yes, Lord, for even the little dogs eat the crumbs that fall from their masters’ table."[/SPEAKER]
Then Jesus answered her, [JESUS]"O woman, your faith is great! Let it be done for you as you desire."[/JESUS] And her daughter was healed from that very hour.
And moving on from there, Jesus went along the Sea of Galilee. He went up on the mountainside and sat down there.
Large crowds came to him, bringing with them the lame, the blind, the crippled, the mute, and many others. They laid them at his feet, and he healed them.
So the crowd was amazed when they saw the mute speaking, the crippled restored, the lame walking, and the blind seeing; and they glorified the God of Israel.

Then Jesus called his disciples to him and said, [JESUS]"I feel a deep compassion for the crowd, because they have already stayed with me for three days and have nothing to eat. I do not want to send them away hungry, or they might collapse on the way."[/JESUS]
And the disciples said to him, [SPEAKER:Disciples]"Where in this desolate place could we get enough bread to satisfy such a large crowd?"[/SPEAKER]
Jesus said to them, [JESUS]"How many loaves do you have?"[/JESUS] They said, [SPEAKER:Disciples]"Seven, and a few small fish."[/JESUS]
After instructing the crowd to recline on the ground,
he took the seven loaves and the fish, and after giving thanks, he broke them and began giving them to the disciples, and the disciples gave them to the crowds.
And everyone ate and was satisfied. They picked up seven large baskets full of the broken pieces that were left over.
Now those who ate were four thousand men, besides women and children.
And after dismissing the crowds, he got into the boat and went to the region of Magadan.

chapters.notes:
**"Ritually wash" (v. 2)**: The Greek *niptontai* refers here specifically to the ceremonial washing (*netilat yadayim*) required by the "tradition of the elders" (the Oral Torah) before eating, rather than for physical hygiene.

**"Must surely be put to death" (v. 4)**: The Greek *thanatō teleutatō* is a literal rendering of the Hebrew emphatic idiom *mōt yūmāt* ("dying he shall die"). The translation "must surely be put to death" captures this legal and linguistic intensity.

**"Dedicated gift" (v. 5)**: The Greek *Dōron* ("gift") translates the Aramaic/Hebrew *Corban*. This refers to the practice of declaring property or money as dedicated to God, which technically exempted the owner from using those funds to support their aging parents, while they often retained use of the funds themselves.

**"Performers" (v. 7)**: As noted in the guidelines, *hypokritai* refers to stage actors. Jesus is characterizing their public piety as a theatrical display.

**"Profanes" (v. 11, 18, 20)**: The Greek *koinoō* means "to make common." In a Levitical context, this means making something ritually "unclean" or unfit for the holy community. "Profane" captures the movement from the sacred/pure to the common/impure better than the generic "defile."

**"Latrine" (v. 17)**: The Greek *aphedrōna* refers to a sewer or a privy. Jesus uses blunt, physiological language to contrast the temporary nature of food with the permanent moral nature of the "heart."

**"Canaanite" (v. 22)**: Matthew uses the archaic term *Chananaia* (Canaanite) rather than the contemporary "Syrophoenician" (used in Mark). This invokes the ancient, biblical enmity between Israel and the inhabitants of the land to highlight the unexpected nature of her faith and Jesus' mercy.

**"Little dogs" (v. 26-27)**: The diminutive *kunariois* refers to household dogs or puppies rather than the wild scavengers of the streets (*kynas*). While still a derogatory ethnic comparison in this context, the woman's response picks up on the domesticity of the term to argue for her place in the "household."

**"Crippled" (v. 30-31)**: The Greek *kyllous* refers specifically to those who are maimed, deformed, or have lost a limb. Many translations collapse this into "lame," but Matthew distinguishes them from the *chōlous* (lame/walking with a limp).

**"Large baskets" (v. 37)**: The word *spyridas* refers to large hampers, distinct from the smaller *kophinous* used in the feeding of the five thousand. These were large enough to lower a man down a wall (as in Acts 9:25).

verses.text: The Pharisees and Sadducees approached him, and to test him they asked him to display a sign from the sky for them.
He replied to them, [JESUS]“When evening comes, you say, ‘It will be fair weather, for the sky is red as fire.’
And in the morning, ‘Today will be stormy, for the sky is red and threatening.’ You know how to discern the face of the sky, yet you cannot discern the signs of the eras.
An evil and unfaithful generation demands a sign, but no sign will be given to it except the sign of Jonah.”[/JESUS] Then he left them behind and went away.
When the disciples went across to the other side of the sea, they forgot to take bread.
Jesus said to them, [JESUS]“Watch out, and be on your guard against the leaven of the Pharisees and Sadducees.”[/JESUS]
They began debating among themselves, saying, [SPEAKER:Disciples]“It is because we didn't bring any bread.”[/SPEAKER]
Aware of this, Jesus said, [JESUS]“You of little faith, why are you debating among yourselves about having no bread?
Do you still not perceive? Do you not remember the five loaves for the five thousand, and how many hand-baskets you gathered?
Or the seven loaves for the four thousand, and how many large hampers you gathered?
How can you not perceive that I was not speaking to you about bread? Be on your guard against the leaven of the Pharisees and Sadducees!”[/JESUS]
Then they understood that he did not tell them to be on guard against the leaven used in bread, but against the teaching of the Pharisees and Sadducees.
When Jesus came into the region of Caesarea Philippi, he questioned his disciples, saying, [JESUS]“Who do people say the Son of Man is?”[/JESUS]
They said, [SPEAKER:Disciples]“Some say John the Baptist; others, Elijah; and still others, Jeremiah or one of the prophets.”[/SPEAKER]
He said to them, [JESUS]“But who do you say that I am?”[/JESUS]
Simon Peter answered, [SPEAKER:Peter]“You are the Christ, the Son of the living God.”[/SPEAKER]
Jesus replied to him, [JESUS]“Blessed are you, Simon Bar-Jonah, because flesh and blood did not reveal this to you, but my Father who is in the heavens.
And I tell you: you are Peter—the Rock—and on this bedrock I will build my assembly, and the gates of Hades will not overpower it.
I will give you the keys of the kingdom of the heavens; whatever you bind on earth will have been bound in the heavens, and whatever you loose on earth will have been loosed in the heavens.”[/JESUS]
Then he strictly ordered the disciples not to tell anyone that he was the Christ.

From that time on, Jesus began to show his disciples that it was necessary for him to go to Jerusalem and suffer many things from the elders, chief priests, and scribes, and to be killed, and on the third day to be raised.
Peter took him aside and began to rebuke him, saying, [SPEAKER:Peter]“Mercy on you, Lord! This must never happen to you!”[/SPEAKER]
But Jesus turned and said to Peter, [JESUS]“Get behind me, Satan! You are a stumbling block to me, because you are not thinking God’s thoughts, but human thoughts.”[/JESUS]
Then Jesus said to his disciples, [JESUS]“If anyone wants to come after me, let him disown himself, take up his cross, and follow me.
For whoever wants to save his life will lose it, but whoever loses his life for my sake will find it.
For what will a person be benefited if he gains the whole world but forfeits his very self? Or what will a person give in exchange for his life?
For the Son of Man is going to come in the glory of his Father with his angels, and then he will repay each person according to their conduct.
Truly I tell you, there are some standing here who will certainly not taste death until they see the Son of Man coming in his kingdom.”[/JESUS]

chapters.notes:
**"Sign from the sky" (v. 1)**: The Greek *ouranos* can mean "heaven" (the dwelling of God) or "the sky." Given the context of the Pharisees looking for a cosmic portent and Jesus’s following response about weather patterns, "sky" is the more immediate sense, though the double meaning remains.

**"Unfaithful generation" (v. 4)**: *Moichalis* literally means "adulterous." In the context of the Hebrew Scriptures (e.g., Hosea, Ezekiel), adultery is the standard metaphor for covenant unfaithfulness to God. "Unfaithful" captures the theological weight for a modern reader better than the literal sexual term.

**"Hand-baskets" vs. "Large hampers" (v. 9–10)**: The Greek uses two different words: *kophinos* (a smaller, stiff wicker basket) in the feeding of the 5,000, and *spyris* (a large, flexible mat-basket or hamper, large enough to hold a man, as in Acts 9:25) in the feeding of the 4,000. Distinguishing them preserves the historical specificity of the two different events.

**"Simon Bar-Jonah" (v. 17)**: Retaining the Aramaic *Bar* ("son of") preserves the Semitic flavor of Jesus's blessing. There is also a likely wordplay with "Jonah" (v. 4) and Peter's father's name.

**"Peter... bedrock... assembly" (v. 18)**: The Greek *Petros* (a stone) and *petra* (bedrock/rock formation) create a wordplay difficult to capture in English. "Peter—the Rock—and on this bedrock" attempts to show the connection. *Ekklēsia* is translated as "assembly" to avoid the later institutional baggage of "church" and to reflect the Greek/LXX meaning of a gathered community of citizens or God’s people.

**"Gates of Hades" (v. 18)**: "Hades" is the realm of the dead. The "gates" represent the power of death to imprison. Jesus is stating that death itself will not be able to contain or conquer his assembly.

**"Will have been bound/loosed" (v. 19)**: The Greek uses periphrastic future perfects (*estai dedemenon/lelumenon*). This suggests that the apostolic "binding and loosing" (rabbinic terms for forbidding and permitting) reflects a reality already determined in heaven, rather than heaven following an earthly lead.

**"Mercy on you" (v. 22)**: *Hileōs soi* is an idiom of deprecation, literally "may God be propitious/merciful to you," used to ward off a terrible thought. "God forbid" is a common translation, but "Mercy on you" preserves the Greek prayer-like root.

**"Life / Very self" (v. 25–26)**: The Greek *psychē* corresponds to the Hebrew *nephesh*, meaning the whole person, the vital life-force, or the "soul." In v. 25, "life" is the clearest fit, but in v. 26, the loss of one's *psychē* is the loss of one's "very self." Using both terms brings out the nuance of the stakes Jesus is describing.

verses.text: Six days later, Jesus took Peter, James, and his brother John and led them up a high mountain by themselves.
There, he was transfigured before them; his face shone with the brilliance of the sun, and his clothes became as white as light itself.
Suddenly, Moses and Elijah appeared to them, talking with him.
Peter reacted by saying to Jesus, [SPEAKER:Peter]“Lord, it is good that we are here. If you wish, I will set up three shelters here—one for you, one for Moses, and one for Elijah.”[/SPEAKER]
While he was still speaking, a radiant cloud overshadowed them, and a voice came from the cloud, saying: [GOD]“This is my Son, the Beloved, in whom I take great delight. Listen to him!”[/GOD]
When the disciples heard this, they fell face-down on the ground, overcome with terror.
But Jesus came and touched them, saying, [JESUS]“Get up. Stop being afraid.”[/JESUS]
And when they raised their eyes, they saw no one except Jesus alone.
As they were coming down the mountain, Jesus commanded them, [JESUS]“Do not tell anyone about this vision until the Son of Man has been raised from the dead.”[/JESUS]
The disciples questioned him, [SPEAKER:The disciples]“Why then do the scribes say that Elijah must come first?”[/SPEAKER]
He answered, [JESUS]“Elijah is indeed coming, and he will restore all things.

But I tell you that Elijah has already come, and they did not recognize him; instead, they did to him whatever they pleased. In the same way, the Son of Man is about to suffer at their hands.”[/JESUS]
Then the disciples understood that he was speaking to them about John the Baptist.
When they reached the crowd, a man approached Jesus, kneeling before him
and saying, [SPEAKER:A man]“Lord, have mercy on my son! He is moon-afflicted and suffers terribly; he often falls into the fire or into the water.
I brought him to your disciples, but they were not able to heal him.”[/SPEAKER]
Jesus answered, [JESUS]“O faithless and perverted generation! How much longer must I be with you? How much longer must I put up with you? Bring him here to me.”[/JESUS]
Then Jesus rebuked the demon and it came out of him, and the boy was healed from 그 moment on.
Later, the disciples came to Jesus privately and asked, [SPEAKER:The disciples]“Why were we unable to cast it out?”[/SPEAKER]

He told them, [JESUS]“Because of the smallness of your trust. For truly I tell you, if you have faith the size of a mustard seed, you will say to this mountain, ‘Move from here to there,’ and it will move. Nothing will be impossible for you.”[/JESUS]
As they were gathering together in Galilee, Jesus said to them, [JESUS]“The Son of Man is about to be delivered into the hands of men,
and they will kill him, and on the third day he will be raised.”[/JESUS] And they were deeply grieved.
When they arrived in Capernaum, the collectors of the temple tax approached Peter and asked, [SPEAKER:Tax collectors]“Does your teacher not pay the two-drachma tax?”[/SPEAKER]

He said, [SPEAKER:Peter]“Yes.”[/SPEAKER] When he entered the house, Jesus spoke first, saying, [JESUS]“What do you think, Simon? From whom do the kings of the earth collect tolls or taxes? From their own sons or from strangers?”[/JESUS]
When Peter said, [SPEAKER:Peter]“From strangers,”[/SPEAKER] Jesus told him, [JESUS]“Then the sons are exempt.

However, so that we do not cause them to stumble, go to the sea, throw in a hook, and take the first fish that comes up. When you open its mouth, you will find a four-drachma coin. Take that and give it to them for me and for yourself.”[/JESUS]

chapters.notes:
**"Transfigured" (v. 2)**: The Greek *metamorphōthē* implies a change of form that stems from an inner reality. For the original audience, this would evoke the shining face of Moses (Exodus 34) but intensified, suggesting Jesus’s divine nature being "unveiled" rather than a mere external change.

**"Shelters" (v. 4)**: The Greek *skēnas* refers to temporary booths or tabernacles. This is a direct allusion to the Festival of Tabernacles (*Sukkot*), during which Jews lived in temporary shelters to remember God dwelling with them in the wilderness. Peter likely thought the Messianic age of "God dwelling with man" had arrived in its fullness.

**"Overshadowed" (v. 5)**: The verb *epeskiazen* is the same word used in the Septuagint to describe the Glory-Cloud (the *Shekinah*) descending upon the Tabernacle (Exodus 40:35). It signals the localized presence of God.

**"Moon-afflicted" (v. 15)**: The Greek *selēniazetai* literally means "to be moon-struck." While it describes what we today identify as epilepsy, the translation retains the lunar connection to reflect the first-century understanding that certain maladies were influenced by the cycles of the moon.

**"Smallness of your trust" (v. 20)**: The Greek *oligopistia* is a compound word Matthew frequently uses. It doesn't mean a total lack of faith, but a "puny" or "underdeveloped" trust that fails to rely on God's power in the moment of crisis.

**"Two-drachma tax" / "Four-drachma coin" (v. 24, 27)**: The *didrachma* (v. 24) was the annual half-shekel tax required of every Jewish male for the upkeep of the Temple. The *statēr* (v. 27) was a specific coin worth four drachmas—exactly the amount needed to cover the tax for two people (Jesus and Peter). 

**"The sons are exempt" (v. 26)**: The Greek *eleutheroi* means "free." Jesus is using a legal analogy: if the Temple is the "House of the Father," then the Son (and by extension his followers) should not be required to pay for its maintenance. He pays not out of legal obligation, but to avoid "stumbling" (*skandalisōmen*) the tax collectors.

verses.text: At that very time the disciples approached Jesus and asked, [SPEAKER:Disciples]“Who, then, is the greatest in the kingdom of the heavens?”[/SPEAKER]
Jesus called a little child to him and had the child stand in the middle of them.
Then he said, [JESUS]“Truly I tell you, unless you turn around and become like little children, you will never enter the kingdom of the heavens.
Therefore, whoever lowers themselves to the status of this little child—that person is the greatest in the kingdom of the heavens.
And whoever welcomes one such child in my name welcomes me.

But if anyone causes one of these little ones who believe in me to trip and fall, it would be better for them to have a massive millstone—the kind turned by a donkey—hung around their neck and to be drowned in the open sea.
How terrible for the world because of the things that cause people to fall! Such traps are bound to come, but how terrible for the person through whom they come.
If your hand or your foot causes you to fall, cut it off and throw it away. It is better for you to enter life crippled or lame than to have two hands or two feet and be thrown into the eternal fire.
And if your eye causes you to fall, gouge it out and throw it away. It is better for you to enter life with one eye than to have two eyes and be thrown into the Gehenna of fire.
See to it that you do not look down on one of these little ones. For I tell you that their angels in the heavens always look upon the face of my Father in the heavens.
What do you think? If a man has a hundred sheep and one of them wanders off, will he not leave the ninety-nine on the hills and go look for the one that is wandering?
And if he happens to find it, truly I tell you, he rejoices over it more than over the ninety-nine that did not wander off.
In the same way, it is not the will of your Father in the heavens that even one of these little ones should be lost.
If your brother sins against you, go and confront him privately, just between the two of you. If he listens to you, you have won back your brother.
But if he will not listen, take one or two others along with you, so that [SCRIPTURE]‘every matter may be established by the testimony of two or three witnesses.’[/SCRIPTURE]
If he refuses to listen to them, tell it to the assembly. And if he refuses to listen even to the assembly, let him be to you just like a foreigner or a tax collector.
Truly I tell you, whatever you bind on earth will have been bound in heaven, and whatever you loose on earth will have been loosed in heaven.
Again, truly I tell you, if two of you on earth agree about any matter they pray for, it will be done for them by my Father in the heavens.
For where two or three are gathered in my name, I am there among them.”[/JESUS]
Then Peter came to him and asked, [SPEAKER:Peter]“Lord, how many times must I forgive my brother when he sins against me? Up to seven times?”[/SPEAKER]
Jesus said to him, [JESUS]“I tell you, not up to seven times, but seventy-seven times.
For this reason, the kingdom of the heavens may be compared to a king who wanted to settle accounts with his servants.
As he began the settlement, a man was brought to him who owed ten thousand talents.
Since he did not have the means to pay it back, the master ordered him to be sold into slavery, along with his wife and children and everything he owned, to pay the debt.
So the servant fell prostrate before him and pleaded, ‘Be patient with me, and I will pay you back everything.’
Then the master of that servant, moved with deep compassion, released him and canceled the debt.
But when that servant went out, he found one of his fellow servants who owed him a hundred silver coins. He grabbed him and began to choke him, saying, ‘Pay back what you owe!’
So his fellow servant fell down and begged him, ‘Be patient with me, and I will pay you back.’
But he refused. Instead, he went and threw him into prison until he could pay back what was owed.
When his fellow servants saw what had happened, they were deeply distressed and went and reported the whole matter to their master.
Then the master summoned him and said, ‘You wicked servant! I canceled that entire debt of yours because you begged me.
Shouldn’t you have had mercy on your fellow servant, just as I had mercy on you?’
And in his anger, the master handed him over to the torturers until he should pay back everything he owed.
This is how my heavenly Father will treat each of you unless you forgive your brother from your heart.”[/JESUS]

chapters.notes:
**Kingdom of the heavens (v. 1)**: The Greek *basileia tōn ouranōn* uses the plural "heavens," reflecting the Hebrew *shamayim*. This preserves the Jewish flavor of Matthew’s Gospel and the cosmological worldview of the audience.

**Turn around (v. 3)**: The Greek *straphēte* suggests a change in direction or orientation. While often translated "be converted," the literal sense of turning back toward the disposition of a child is more immediate here.

**Lower themselves to the status (v. 4)**: *Tapeinōsei heauton* is usually "humbles himself." However, in the first century, "humility" was not a private psychological feeling but a social reality. Children had the lowest social status; Jesus is telling his followers to voluntarily occupy that lowest rung of the social ladder.

**Massive millstone (v. 6)**: The Greek specifies a *mulos onikos*—a millstone turned by a donkey. This was significantly larger and heavier than the small stones used in hand-mills, emphasizing the absolute finality of the judgment described.

**Gehenna (v. 9)**: Rather than "hell," which carries centuries of later theological baggage, "Gehenna" refers to the Valley of Hinnom. To a first-century Jew, this evokes a specific place associated with fire and judgment (derived from its history of child sacrifice and later as a smoldering refuse heap), making it a more precise cultural reference.

**Assembly (v. 17)**: The Greek *ekklēsia* refers to a gathering or congregation. Using "church" can be anachronistic, suggesting a later institutional structure. "Assembly" better captures the communal, local gathering Jesus is describing.

**Bind and loose (v. 18)**: These are technical Rabbinic terms. To "bind" was to forbid something; to "loose" was to permit it. Jesus is giving the assembly the authority to interpret and apply the law to specific communal conflicts.

**Seventy-seven times (v. 22)**: The Greek *hebdomēkontakis hepta* is an allusion to the vengeance of Lamech in Genesis 4:24. Jesus is deliberately reversing Lamech's "seventy-sevenfold" vengeance into a "seventy-sevenfold" (limitless) forgiveness.

**Ten thousand talents (v. 24)**: This is an astronomical, hyper-inflated sum. A single talent was worth about 6,000 denarii (6,000 days of labor). Ten thousand was the highest number for which the Greeks had a name. This debt is roughly equivalent to several billion dollars—an impossible amount for a servant to ever repay.

**Hundred silver coins (v. 28)**: The Greek *hekaton dēnaria* (one hundred denarii) represents about one hundred days' wages for a laborer. While significant, it is a tiny fraction (roughly 1/600,000th) of the debt the first servant had been forgiven.

**Torturers (v. 34)**: *Basanistais* refers specifically to those who examine prisoners by torture. In the ancient world, debtors' prisons often involved physical mistreatment to pressure the debtor's family into paying. It underscores the severity of the master’s reversal of mercy.

verses.text: Now when Jesus had finished these sayings, he departed from Galilee and came into the region of Judea across the Jordan.
Large crowds followed him, and he healed them there.
Some Pharisees approached him to test him, asking, [CROWD]“Is it permissible for a man to divorce his wife for any cause whatsoever?”[/CROWD]
He answered them, [JESUS]“Have you not read that [SCRIPTURE]‘the Creator from the beginning made them male and female,’[/SCRIPTURE]
and said, [SCRIPTURE]‘For this reason a man shall leave his father and mother and be joined to his wife, and the two shall become one flesh’[/SCRIPTURE]?
So they are no longer two, but one flesh. Therefore, what God has yoked together, let no human separate.”[/JESUS]
They said to him, [CROWD]“Why then did Moses command us to give her a certificate of dismissal and divorce her?”[/CROWD]
He said to them, [JESUS]“Moses permitted you to divorce your wives because of your hard-heartedness, but from the beginning it was not this way.
I tell you that whoever divorces his wife, except for sexual immorality, and marries another, commits adultery—and the one who marries a divorced woman commits adultery.”[/JESUS]
The disciples said to him, [CROWD]“If such is the legal case of a man with his wife, it is better not to marry.”[/CROWD]
But he said to them, [JESUS]“Not everyone can accept this teaching, but only those to whom it has been given.

For there are eunuchs who were born that way from their mother’s womb, and there are eunuchs who were made eunuchs by people, and there are eunuchs who made themselves eunuchs for the sake of the kingdom of the heavens. Let the one who is able to accept this, accept it.”[/JESUS]
Then children were brought to him so that he might lay his hands on them and pray, but the disciples rebuked those who brought them.
But Jesus said, [JESUS]“Allow the children to come to me and do not hinder them, for the kingdom of the heavens belongs to such as these.”[/JESUS]
And after laying his hands on them, he went on from there.
And behold, a man approached him and said, [SPEAKER:Young Man]“Teacher, what good thing must I do so that I may have eternal life?”[/SPEAKER]
He said to him, [JESUS]“Why do you ask me about what is good? One is good. But if you wish to enter into life, keep the commandments.”[/JESUS]
[SPEAKER:Young Man]“Which ones?”[/SPEAKER] the man asked. Jesus said, [JESUS]“[SCRIPTURE]‘Do not murder, Do not commit adultery, Do not steal, Do not bear false witness,
Honor your father and mother,’[/SCRIPTURE] and [SCRIPTURE]‘Love your neighbor as yourself.’[/SCRIPTURE]”[/JESUS]
The young man said to him, [SPEAKER:Young Man]“I have guarded all of these. What do I still lack?”[/SPEAKER]
Jesus said to him, [JESUS]“If you wish to be complete, go, sell your possessions and give the money to the poor, and you will have treasure in the heavens; then come, follow me.”[/JESUS]
But when the young man heard this word, he went away grieving, for he had many holdings.
Then Jesus said to his disciples, [JESUS]“Truly I tell you, it will be difficult for a wealthy person to enter the kingdom of the heavens.
Again I tell you, it is easier for a camel to go through the eye of a needle than for a wealthy person to enter the kingdom of God.”[/JESUS]
When the disciples heard this, they were utterly struck with astonishment and said, [CROWD]“Who then can be saved?”[/CROWD]
Jesus looked straight at them and said, [JESUS]“With humans this is impossible, but with God all things are possible.”[/JESUS]
Then Peter responded, [SPEAKER:Peter]“Look, we have left everything and followed you. What then will there be for us?”[/SPEAKER]

Jesus said to them, [JESUS]“Truly I tell you, in the rebirth of the world, when the Son of Man sits on his glorious throne, you who have followed me will also sit on twelve thrones, judging the twelve tribes of Israel.
And everyone who has left houses or brothers or sisters or father or mother or wife or children or fields for the sake of my name will receive a hundredfold and will inherit eternal life.
But many who are first will be last, and the last first.”[/JESUS]

chapters.notes:
**"For any cause whatsoever" (v. 3)**: The Greek *kata pasan aitian* reflects a specific first-century legal debate between the Rabbinic schools of Hillel and Shammai regarding Deuteronomy 24:1. The Hillelites argued a man could divorce his wife for "any cause," even minor domestic failings; the Shammaites restricted it to sexual indecency. The Pharisees are asking Jesus to take a side in this specific halakhic dispute.

**"Hard-heartedness" (v. 8)**: *Sklērokardia* refers to a stubborn, unyielding spiritual condition—a refusal to be shaped by God’s original intent for creation.

**"Sexual immorality" (v. 9)**: *Porneia* is a broad term for illicit sexual behavior. It is distinct from *moicheia* (adultery), though it includes it. In a Jewish context, it could also refer to marriages within prohibited degrees of kinship (Leviticus 18).

**"Eunuchs" (v. 12)**: The term refers both to physical eunuchs and, metaphorically, to those who choose a life of celibacy to remain fully available for the work of the Kingdom.

**"Complete" (v. 21)**: *Teleios* is often translated as "perfect," but in Matthew’s Jewish context (evoking the Hebrew *tamim*), it means to be "whole," "undivided," or "blameless" in one's devotion to God. Jesus is challenging the man to move from a checklist of commandments to an undivided heart.

**"The rebirth of the world" (v. 28)**: *Palingenesia* refers to the "new genesis" or "renewal of all things." It evokes the prophetic hope of a restored creation, where the world is "born again" into its intended state under God's rule.

**"Judging" (v. 28)**: *Krinontes* carries the sense of the Old Testament "Judges"—not merely legal sentencing, but ruling, governing, and setting things right within the community of Israel.

verses.text: [JESUS]"For the Kingdom of the Heavens is like a man, the master of an estate, who went out early at dawn to hire laborers for his vineyard.
After agreeing with the laborers for a denarius for the day, he sent them into his vineyard.
Going out again around the third hour, he saw others standing in the marketplace unemployed.
And to those he said, [JESUS]'You go into the vineyard too, and I will give you whatever is fair.'[/JESUS]
So they went. Going out again around the sixth hour and the ninth hour, he did the same.
Then, around the eleventh hour, he went out and found others standing there, and he says to them, [JESUS]'Why have you been standing here all day without work?'[/JESUS]
They say to him, [SPEAKER:Laborers]'Because no one hired us.'[/SPEAKER] He says to them, [JESUS]'You go into the vineyard too.'[/JESUS]
When evening came, the owner of the vineyard says to his manager, [SPEAKER:Owner]'Call the laborers and pay them their wages, beginning with the last ones and ending with the first.'[/SPEAKER]
When those hired around the eleventh hour came, they each received a denarius.
So when the first came, they assumed they would receive more, but they also received—each one of them—a denarius.
Upon receiving it, they began grumbling against the master of the estate,
saying, [SPEAKER:Laborers]'These last worked only one hour, and you have made them equal to us who have carried the burden of the day’s work and the scorching heat!'[/SPEAKER]
But he answered one of them and said, [JESUS]'Friend, I am doing you no wrong. Did you not agree with me for a denarius?
Take what is yours and go. I choose to give to this last person the same as I gave to you.
Am I not permitted to do what I want with what belongs to me? Or is your eye evil because I am good?'[/JESUS]
So the last shall be first, and the first shall be last."[/JESUS]
While Jesus was going up to Jerusalem, he took the twelve disciples aside privately and said to them on the way,
[JESUS]"Look, we are going up to Jerusalem, and the Son of Man will be handed over to the chief priests and legal scholars. They will condemn him to death
and hand him over to the nations to be mocked, flogged, and crucified; and on the third day, he will be raised."[/JESUS]
Then the mother of the sons of Zebedee approached him with her sons, kneeling down and asking something from him.

He said to her, [JESUS]"What do you want?"[/JESUS] She says to him, [SPEAKER:Mother]"Declare that these two sons of mine may sit, one at your right hand and one at your left, in your kingdom."[/SPEAKER]
Jesus answered, [JESUS]"You do not know what you are asking. Are you able to drink the cup that I am about to drink?"[/JESUS] They say to him, [SPEAKER:James and John]"We are able."[/SPEAKER]
He says to them, [JESUS]"You will indeed drink my cup, but to sit at my right hand and at my left is not mine to give; rather, it is for those for whom it has been prepared by my Father."[/JESUS]
When the ten heard this, they were deeply indignant with the two brothers.
But Jesus called them over and said, [JESUS]"You know that the rulers of the nations lord it over them, and their 'great ones' exercise absolute authority over them.
It shall not be this way among you. Instead, whoever wants to become great among you must be your servant,
and whoever wants to be first among you must be your slave—
just as the Son of Man did not come to be served, but to serve, and to give his life as a ransom in place of many."[/JESUS]
As they were departing from Jericho, a large crowd followed him.
And look, there were two blind men sitting by the roadside. When they heard that Jesus was passing by, they cried out, [SPEAKER:Blind Men]"Lord, have mercy on us, Son of David!"[/SPEAKER]
The crowd rebuked them, telling them to be quiet, but they cried out all the louder, [SPEAKER:Blind Men]"Lord, have mercy on us, Son of David!"[/SPEAKER]
Jesus stopped, called to them, and said, [JESUS]"What do you want me to do for you?"[/JESUS]
They say to him, [SPEAKER:Blind Men]"Lord, let our eyes be opened."[/SPEAKER]
Moved with deep compassion, Jesus touched their eyes. Immediately they regained their sight and followed him.

chapters.notes:
**"Master of an estate" (v. 1, 11)**: The Greek *oikodespotēs* literally means "house-master." In the context of a vineyard, it refers to a landowner who manages an estate. Using "master of the estate" maintains the status distinction between him and the day laborers.

**"Denarius" (v. 2, 9, 10, 13)**: A Roman silver coin. In the first century, a single denarius was the standard, subsistence-level daily wage for a common laborer. Retaining the term preserves the specific economic context of the parable.

**"Unemployed" / "Without work" (v. 3, 6)**: The Greek *argous* literally means "idle" or "not working." In a marketplace context, these were not people being lazy, but day laborers waiting for a contract. "Unemployed" or "without work" better reflects their socio-economic vulnerability.

**"Is your eye evil" (v. 15)**: The Greek *ophthalmos sou ponēros* reflects a common Jewish idiom (the "evil eye") referring to envy, jealousy, or stinginess. Many translations flatten this to "Are you envious," but retaining the "eye" imagery preserves the Aramaic/Hebrew flavor of the idiom used by Jesus.

**"Legal scholars" (v. 18)**: The *grammateis* (traditionally "scribes") were the experts in the interpretation and application of the Torah (the Law). "Legal scholars" better conveys their professional and religious function to a modern reader.

**"Nations" (v. 19, 25)**: The Greek *ethnē* (traditionally "Gentiles") refers to the non-Jewish peoples. In v. 19, it specifically points to the Roman authorities; in v. 25, it refers to the political structures of the pagan world.

**"Lord it over... exercise absolute authority" (v. 25)**: The Greek verbs *katakyrieuousin* and *katexousiazousin* use the prefix *kata-* ("down/against") to intensify the meaning. These are not just "ruling" but "ruling down upon" people—dominating them.

**"Servant" vs. "Slave" (v. 26, 27)**: A distinction is made between *diakonos* (an attendant or waiter) and *doulos* (a bondservant or slave). Jesus's rhetoric moves from the common "attendant" to the lowest social rung, the "slave," to emphasize the reversal of status.

**"Ransom" (v. 28)**: The Greek *lytron* refers to the price paid to liberate a slave or a prisoner of war. It carries a specific weight of "redemption price."

**"Moved with deep compassion" (v. 34)**: The Greek *splagchnistheis* is a visceral verb, literally referring to the "bowels" or "guts." It describes a physical sensation of pity. "Moved with deep compassion" is an attempt to capture this intensity.

verses.text: When they drew near to Jerusalem and came to Bethphage at the Mount of Olives, Jesus sent two disciples,
saying to them, [JESUS]“Go into the village ahead of you, and immediately you will find a donkey tied there and a colt with her. Untie them and bring them to me.
If anyone says anything to you, you are to say, ‘The Master has need of them,’ and he will send them at once.”[/JESUS]
This took place to fulfill what was spoken through the prophet:
[SCRIPTURE]“Tell the daughter of Zion: ‘Look, your King is coming to you, gentle in his strength and mounted on a donkey, even on a colt, the foal of a beast of burden.’”[/SCRIPTURE]
The disciples went and did just as Jesus had directed them.
They brought the donkey and the colt and laid their garments on them, and he sat upon them.
A very large crowd spread their own garments on the road, while others were cutting branches from the trees and spreading them on the road.
The crowds that went ahead of him and those that followed were shouting, [CROWD]“Hosanna to the Son of David! Blessed is the one who comes in the name of the Lord! Hosanna in the highest!”[/CROWD]
When he entered Jerusalem, the entire city was seismically shaken, asking, [CROWD]“Who is this?”[/CROWD]
The crowds were saying, [CROWD]“This is the prophet Jesus, the one from Nazareth of Galilee.”[/CROWD]
Jesus entered the temple precincts and drove out all who were selling and buying in the temple. He overturned the tables of the money-changers and the benches of those selling doves.
And he said to them, [JESUS]“It is written: [SCRIPTURE]‘My house shall be called a house of prayer,’[/SCRIPTURE] but you are making it [SCRIPTURE]‘a hideout for bandits.’[/SCRIPTURE]”[/JESUS]
The blind and the lame came to him in the temple, and he healed them.
But when the chief priests and the scribes saw the wonders he performed, and the children shouting in the temple, [CROWD]“Hosanna to the Son of David!”[/CROWD] they were indignant.

They said to him, [SPEAKER:The chief priests and scribes]“Do you hear what these children are saying?”[/SPEAKER] Jesus said to them, [JESUS]“Yes. Have you never read: [SCRIPTURE]‘From the mouths of infants and nursing babies you have prepared perfect praise’[/SCRIPTURE]?”[/JESUS]
And leaving them behind, he went out of the city to Bethany and spent the night there.
Early the next morning, as he was returning to the city, he was hungry.

Seeing a lone fig tree by the road, he went up to it and found nothing on it but leaves. He said to it, [JESUS]“May no fruit ever come from you again, for the rest of the age!”[/JESUS] And the fig tree withered instantly.
When the disciples saw this, they were amazed and asked, [SPEAKER:The disciples]“How did the fig tree wither so instantly?”[/SPEAKER]

Jesus answered them, [JESUS]“Truly I tell you, if you have faith and do not waver in your heart, you will not only do what was done to the fig tree, but even if you say to this mountain, ‘Be lifted up and thrown into the sea,’ it will happen.
Everything you ask for in prayer, if you believe, you will receive.”[/JESUS]

When he entered the temple, the chief priests and the elders of the people approached him while he was teaching and said, [SPEAKER:The chief priests and elders]“By what kind of authority are you doing these things? And who gave you this authority?”[/SPEAKER]
Jesus answered them, [JESUS]“I will also ask you one question. If you tell me the answer, then I will tell you by what authority I do these things.

The baptism of John—where did it come from? From heaven or from human origin?”[/JESUS] They began debating among themselves, saying, [SPEAKER:The chief priests and elders]“If we say, ‘From heaven,’ he will say to us, ‘Then why did you not believe him?’
But if we say, ‘From human origin,’ we are afraid of the crowd, for they all hold John to be a prophet.”[/SPEAKER]
So they answered Jesus, [SPEAKER:The chief priests and elders]“We do not know.”[/SPEAKER] He said to them, [JESUS]“Neither will I tell you by what authority I do these things.
But what do you think? A man had two children. He went to the first and said, [SPEAKER:The father]‘Child, go and work in the vineyard today.’[/SPEAKER]
He answered, [SPEAKER:The first son]‘I will not,’[/SPEAKER] but later he regretted it and went.
The father went to the second and said the same thing. He answered, [SPEAKER:The second son]‘I’ll go, sir,’[/SPEAKER] but he did not go.

Which of the two did the will of the father?”[/JESUS] They said, [SPEAKER:The chief priests and elders]“The first.”[/SPEAKER] Jesus said to them, [JESUS]“Truly I tell you, the tax collectors and the prostitutes are entering the kingdom of God ahead of you.

For John came to you in the way of righteousness and you did not believe him, but the tax collectors and the prostitutes believed him. And even after you saw this, you did not later regret it and believe him.

Listen to another parable. There was a master of a house who planted a vineyard. He put a wall around it, dug a winepress in it, and built a watchtower. Then he leased it to tenant farmers and went abroad.
When the harvest season drew near, he sent his servants to the tenants to collect his fruit.
But the tenants seized his servants; they beat one, killed another, and stoned a third.
Again, he sent other servants, more than the first, and they treated them the same way.
Finally, he sent his son to them, saying, [SPEAKER:The master]‘They will respect my son.’[/SPEAKER]
But when the tenants saw the son, they said among themselves, [SPEAKER:The tenants]‘This is the heir. Come, let us kill him and take his inheritance!’[/SPEAKER]
So they seized him, threw him out of the vineyard, and killed him.
Therefore, when the owner of the vineyard comes, what will he do to those tenants?”[/JESUS]

They said to him, [SPEAKER:The chief priests and elders]“He will bring those wretched men to a wretched end and lease the vineyard to other tenants who will give him the fruit in its season.”[/SPEAKER]

Jesus said to them, [JESUS]“Have you never read in the Scriptures: [SCRIPTURE]‘The stone that the builders rejected has become the cornerstone; this was the Lord’s doing, and it is marvelous in our eyes’[/SCRIPTURE]?
For this reason I tell you, the kingdom of God will be taken away from you and given to a people that produces its fruit.
And the one who falls on this stone will be shattered to pieces; and on whomever it falls, it will crush him like chaff.”[/JESUS]
When the chief priests and the Pharisees heard his parables, they knew he was speaking about them.
Although they were looking for a way to arrest him, they feared the crowds, since the people held him to be a prophet.

chapters.notes:
**"Gentle in his strength" (v. 5)**: The Greek *praÿs* is often rendered "meek," but in the first century, it carried the nuance of controlled strength or power under discipline, not weakness.

**"Hosanna" (v. 9, 15)**: Retained as a transliteration. Derived from the Hebrew *Hoshia-na* ("Save, please"), it had become a standard liturgical acclamation of praise and a plea for Messianic intervention.

**"Seismically shaken" (v. 10)**: The Greek *eseisthē* is the root of the English "seismic." It implies a violent shaking or agitation of the entire city, signaling the magnitude of the event.

**"Hideout for bandits" (v. 13)**: The Greek *lēstōn* refers to more than simple thieves; it often designated violent insurrectionists or bandits. The "hideout" or "cave" imagery (quoting Jeremiah 7:11) suggests a place where criminals feel safe after committing their crimes, rather than a place where they commit the crimes themselves.

**"For the rest of the age" (v. 19)**: The Greek *eis ton aiōna* is often translated "forever," but "age" captures the Jewish concept of the current age versus the age to come.

**"Waver in your heart" (v. 21)**: The verb *diakrithēte* suggests being divided in one’s own mind or doubting one's own conviction.

**"Regretted" (v. 29, 32)**: The verb *metamelētheis* denotes a change of mind or feeling regret, distinct from the more common term for repentance (*metanoeō*), though they are closely related in this context of shifting one's stance toward John's message.

**"Cornerstone" (v. 42)**: *Kephalēn gōnias* literally means the "head of the corner." This could refer to the foundation stone or the capstone that completes the arch; in either case, it is the most vital stone in the structure.

**"Crush him like chaff" (v. 44)**: The verb *likmēsei* refers to winnowing grain. When the heavy stone falls on someone, it doesn't just crush them; it scatters them like dust in the wind.

verses.text: And Jesus spoke to them in parables again, saying:
[JESUS]“The kingdom of the heavens can be compared to a man, a king, who prepared a wedding banquet for his son.
He sent his slaves to summon those who had been invited to the banquet, but they were not willing to come.

Again, he sent other slaves, saying, ‘Tell those who have been invited: “Look, I have prepared my feast; my bulls and fattened livestock have been slaughtered, and everything is ready. Come to the wedding banquet.”’
But they treated the invitation with contempt and went away—one to his own farm, another to his business.
The rest seized his slaves, mistreated them, and killed them.
The king was enraged. He sent his armies, destroyed those murderers, and burned their city.
Then he said to his slaves, ‘The wedding banquet is ready, but those who were invited were not worthy.
Therefore, go to the thoroughfares where the city roads lead out, and invite everyone you find to the wedding banquet.’
Those slaves went out into the streets and gathered everyone they found, both the evil and the good, and the wedding hall was filled with guests.
But when the king came in to look at the guests, he saw a man there who was not dressed in a wedding garment.
And he said to him, [SPEAKER:King]‘Friend, how did you get in here without a wedding garment?’[/SPEAKER] But the man was struck speechless.
Then the king said to the attendants, [SPEAKER:King]‘Bind him hand and foot and throw him into the outer darkness; in that place there will be weeping and gnashing of teeth.’[/SPEAKER]
For many are invited, but few are chosen.”[/JESUS]
Then the Pharisees went and plotted how they might trap him in his speech.

They sent their disciples to him along with the Herodians, saying, [SPEAKER:Pharisees]“Teacher, we know that you are sincere and that you teach the way of God in accordance with the truth. You are not swayed by anyone’s opinion, because you do not show partiality based on a person’s status.
Tell us, then, what do you think? Is it lawful to pay the poll tax to Caesar, or not?”[/SPEAKER]
But Jesus, knowing their malice, said, [JESUS]“Why are you testing me, you performers?
Show me the coin used for the tax.”[/JESUS] They brought him a denarius.
And he said to them, [JESUS]“Whose image is this, and whose inscription?”[/JESUS]
They said to him, [CROWD]“Caesar’s.”[/CROWD] Then he said to them, [JESUS]“Therefore, give back to Caesar the things that are Caesar’s, and to God the things that are God’s.”[/JESUS]
When they heard this, they were amazed; and they left him and went away.
On that same day, Sadducees (who say there is no resurrection) came to him and questioned him,

saying, [SPEAKER:Sadducees]“Teacher, Moses said, [SCRIPTURE]‘If a man dies without having children, his brother shall marry the widow as next-of-kin and raise up offspring for his brother.’[/SCRIPTURE]
Now there were seven brothers among us. The first married and died, and having no offspring, he left his wife to his brother.
The same happened with the second and the third, down to the seventh.
Finally, the woman died.
In the resurrection, then, whose wife of the seven will she be? For they all had her.”[/SPEAKER]
Jesus answered them, [JESUS]“You are led astray because you know neither the Scriptures nor the power of God.
For in the resurrection, people neither marry nor are given in marriage, but are like angels of God in heaven.
But regarding the resurrection of the dead, have you not read what was spoken to you by God, saying:
[SCRIPTURE]‘I am the God of Abraham, and the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob’?[/SCRIPTURE] He is not the God of the dead, but of the living.”[/JESUS]
And when the crowds heard this, they were spellbound by his teaching.
When the Pharisees heard that he had silenced the Sadducees, they gathered together.
One of them, an expert in the law, tested him with a question:
[SPEAKER:Lawyer]“Teacher, which is the great commandment in the Law?”[/SPEAKER]
He said to him, [JESUS]“[SCRIPTURE]‘You shall love the Lord your God with all your heart, and with all your soul, and with all your mind.’[/SCRIPTURE]
This is the great and first commandment.
And a second is like it: [SCRIPTURE]‘You shall love your neighbor as yourself.’[/SCRIPTURE]
On these two commandments hang the whole Law and the Prophets.”[/JESUS]
While the Pharisees were gathered together, Jesus questioned them,
saying, [JESUS]“What is your opinion concerning the Christ? Whose son is he?”[/JESUS] They said to him, [CROWD]“The son of David.”[/CROWD]
He said to them, [JESUS]“How then does David, inspired by the Spirit, call him ‘Lord,’ saying:
[SCRIPTURE]‘The Lord said to my Lord, “Sit at my right hand, until I put your enemies underneath your feet”’?[/SCRIPTURE]
If David then calls him ‘Lord,’ how is he his son?”[/JESUS]
No one was able to answer him a word, nor did anyone dare to question him further from that day on.

chapters.notes:
**"Wedding Banquet" (v. 2)**: The Greek *gamous* is plural, reflecting the multi-day nature of ancient Near Eastern wedding festivities. "Banquet" captures the specific event to which they are summoned.

**"Thoroughfares" (v. 9)**: The Greek *diexodous tōn hodōn* refers to the places where city streets exit into the open country—busy intersections where one would find travelers and the marginalized who did not live within the city walls.

**"Friend" (v. 12)**: The term *hetaire* is more precisely "comrade" or "associate." In Matthew, it is consistently used by a superior to address someone who is acting in bad faith (cf. 20:13, 26:50). It carries a tone of distant, ironic formality.

**"Struck speechless" (v. 12)**: *Ephimōthē* literally means "to be muzzled." It describes a sudden, forced silence, as if the man’s mouth was physically clamped shut by his own guilt.

**"Performers" (v. 18)**: *Hypokritai* refers to stage actors. Jesus is not just calling them "hypocrites" in the modern sense of moral inconsistency, but is highlighting that their public piety and their questioning are part of a theatrical role played for an audience.

**"Poll tax" (v. 17)**: *Kenson* (from the Latin *census*) refers specifically to the per-capita tax paid directly to the Roman treasury, a point of extreme political and religious tension in Judea.

**"Give back" (v. 21)**: *Apodote* means to "render" or "give back" what is already owed. Since the coin bears Caesar’s image, it belongs to his sphere. By extension, because humans bear God’s image (Genesis 1:26), they must "give back" their whole selves to God.

**"Marry nor are given in marriage" (v. 30)**: This reflects the gendered social reality of the time—men "took" wives (*gamousin*) and women were "given" (*gamizontai*) by their fathers.

**"Spellbound" (v. 33)**: *Exeplessonto* means to be struck with such amazement that one is virtually knocked off balance. "Astonished" is too weak for the visceral reaction of the crowds.

**"Hang" (v. 40)**: *Krematai* suggests that the entire legal and prophetic framework is suspended from these two commands, like a door on its hinges or a weight on a peg. If these two are removed, the whole system collapses.

**"Underneath your feet" (v. 44)**: Following the SBLGNT reading *hypokatō* (underneath) rather than the traditional *hypopodion* (footstool). This emphasizes the total subjugation of enemies in ancient Near Eastern victory imagery.

verses.text: Then Jesus spoke to the crowds and to his disciples,
[JESUS]"The scholars of the law and the Pharisees have taken their seat upon the chair of Moses.
Therefore, do and observe everything they tell you, but do not act according to their deeds; for they speak, but they do not act.
They tie up heavy loads and lay them on the shoulders of others, but they themselves are not willing to lift a finger to move them.
They perform all their works to be watched by others. For they widen their phylacteries and enlarge the tassels of their robes;
they love the place of honor at banquets and the front seats in the synagogues,
and greetings in the marketplaces, and to be called 'Rabbi' by people.
But you are not to be called 'Rabbi,' for you have only one Teacher, and you are all brothers.
And do not call anyone on earth 'Father,' for you have only one Father—the Heavenly One.
Nor are you to be called 'Instructors,' because your Instructor is one: the Messiah.
The one who is greatest among you shall be your servant.
Whoever exalts himself will be humbled, and whoever humbles himself will be exalted.

Woe to you, scholars of the law and Pharisees, you performers! For you shut the Kingdom of the Heavens in people’s faces. You yourselves do not enter, nor do you allow those who are trying to enter to go in.

Woe to you, scholars of the law and Pharisees, you performers! For you travel over sea and land to make a single convert, and when he becomes one, you make him twice as much a son of Gehenna as yourselves.
Woe to you, blind guides, who say, 'If someone swears by the temple, it means nothing; but if someone swears by the gold of the temple, he is bound by his oath.'
You blind fools! Which is greater: the gold, or the temple that made the gold holy?
And you say, 'If someone swears by the altar, it means nothing; but if someone swears by the gift on top of it, he is bound.'
You blind men! Which is greater: the gift, or the altar that makes the gift holy?
Therefore, the one who swears by the altar swears by it and by everything on it.
And the one who swears by the temple swears by it and by the One who dwells in it.
And the one who swears by heaven swears by the throne of God and by the One who sits upon it.

Woe to you, scholars of the law and Pharisees, you performers! For you tithe mint and dill and cumin, but you have neglected the weightier matters of the law: justice and mercy and faithfulness. These were the things you should have practiced, without neglecting the others.
Blind guides! You strain out the gnat but swallow the camel!
Woe to you, scholars of the law and Pharisees, you performers! For you clean the outside of the cup and the dish, but inside they are full of greed and self-indulgence.
Blind Pharisee! First clean the inside of the cup and the dish, so that the outside of it may also become clean.

Woe to you, scholars of the law and Pharisees, you performers! For you are like whitewashed tombs, which look beautiful on the outside but inside are full of the bones of the dead and every kind of uncleanness.
In the same way, on the outside you appear righteous to people, but inside you are full of performance and lawlessness.
Woe to you, scholars of the law and Pharisees, you performers! For you build the tombs of the prophets and decorate the monuments of the righteous,
and you say, 'If we had lived in the days of our ancestors, we would not have been their partners in shedding the blood of the prophets.'
Thus you testify against yourselves that you are the sons of those who murdered the prophets.
Go ahead, then—fill up the measure of your ancestors!
You snakes! You brood of vipers! How can you escape the judgment of Gehenna?

Because of this, look—I am sending you prophets and wise men and scholars of the law. Some of them you will kill and crucify, and some of them you will flog in your synagogues and pursue from town to town.

As a result, there will come upon you all the righteous blood shed on the earth, from the blood of righteous Abel to the blood of Zechariah son of Barachiah, whom you murdered between the sanctuary and the altar.
Truly I tell you, all these things will come upon this generation.

Jerusalem, Jerusalem, who kills the prophets and stones those sent to her! How often I wanted to gather your children together, the way a hen gathers her chicks under her wings, and you were not willing.
Look, your house is left to you desolate.
For I tell you, you will not see me again until you say, [SCRIPTURE]"Blessed is the one who comes in the name of the Lord."[/SCRIPTURE]"[/JESUS]

chapters.notes:
**Chair of Moses (v. 2)**: This refers to a literal stone seat found in ancient synagogues where the authoritative teacher of the Law would sit to deliver instruction. It symbolizes the institutional authority of the scribes (legal scholars).

**Performers (v. 13, 15, 23, 25, 27, 29)**: The Greek *hypokritai* refers to stage actors or people wearing masks in a play. Jesus is characterizing their religious life as a theatrical display for an audience rather than an authentic internal reality.

**Phylacteries and Tassels (v. 5)**: These are specific Jewish ritual items. Phylacteries (*tefillin*) are small leather boxes containing scripture worn on the arm and forehead. Tassels (*tzitzit*) are ritual fringes on the corners of garments (Num 15:38). Jesus critiques the performative "enlarging" of these items for status.

**Son of Gehenna (v. 15, 33)**: *Gehenna* (the Valley of Hinnom) was a site outside Jerusalem associated with burning refuse and ancient child sacrifice, serving as a potent first-century metaphor for final judgment and destruction.

**Justice, mercy, and faithfulness (v. 23)**: This is a clear allusion to Micah 6:8 ("to do justice, and to love kindness [mercy], and to walk humbly with your God"). Jesus identifies these as the "weightier" or more substantial demands of the Torah.

**Strain out the gnat but swallow the camel (v. 24)**: This preserves an Aramaic wordplay. The Aramaic word for gnat is *qalma* and for camel is *gamla*. The two words sound nearly identical, highlighting the absurdity of the Pharisees' meticulousness regarding minor matters while ignoring massive ones.

**Lawlessness (v. 28)**: The Greek *anomia* literally means "being without law" or "violating the law." It is ironic here, as Jesus accuses those obsessed with the Law of being fundamentally lawless in their hearts.

**Zechariah son of Barachiah (v. 35)**: In the arrangement of the Hebrew Scriptures (the Tanakh), Abel is the first martyr (Genesis 4) and Zechariah is the last (2 Chronicles 24:20-22, which concludes the traditional Hebrew canon). This phrase encompasses the entire history of biblical martyrdom.

**House (v. 38)**: In this context, "house" likely refers to the Temple, which was the "House of God." Its desolation implies the withdrawal of the divine presence.

verses.text: As Jesus was leaving the temple grounds and walking away, his disciples came up to him to point out the various buildings of the temple complex.
But he answered them, [JESUS]“Do you see all these things? Truly I tell you, not one stone will be left here upon another; every single one will be torn down.”[/JESUS]

Later, as he was sitting on the Mount of Olives, the disciples approached him privately. [SPEAKER:The Disciples]“Tell us,”[/SPEAKER] they said, [SPEAKER:The Disciples]“when will these things happen? And what will be the sign of your royal presence and of the consummation of the age?”[/SPEAKER]
Jesus answered them, [JESUS]“Watch out so that no one misleads you.
For many will come claiming my name and authority, saying, ‘I am the Anointed One,’ and they will mislead many people.
You are going to hear about wars and rumors of wars. See to it that you are not thrown into a panic. These things must happen, but the end is not yet.
For nation will rise up against nation and kingdom against kingdom, and there will be famines and earthquakes in various places.
All these things are merely the beginning of the birth-throes.
Then they will hand you over to be tortured and will kill you, and you will be hated by all the nations because of my name.
At 그 time many will be tripped up and fall away; they will betray one another and hate one another.
Many false prophets will arise and lead many astray.
And because lawlessness will be multiplied, the love of most people will grow cold.
But the one who endures to the end—that is the one who will be saved.
And this good news of the kingdom will be proclaimed throughout the whole inhabited world as a testimony to all the nations, and then the end will come.
So, when you see [SCRIPTURE]‘the appalling desecration’[/SCRIPTURE] spoken of through the prophet Daniel, standing in the holy place”[/JESUS] (let the reader understand) [JESUS]“
then those in Judea must flee to the mountains.
A man on the roof must not go down to get the belongings out of his house,
and a man in the field must not turn back to get his cloak.
How terrible it will be for women who are pregnant or nursing infants in those days!
Pray that your flight does not happen in winter or on a Sabbath.
For at 그 time there will be a great ordeal, such as has not happened from the beginning of the world until now, and never will happen again.
In fact, if those days had not been cut short, no human being would be saved. But for the sake of the chosen ones, those days will be cut short.
If anyone says to you at that time, ‘Look! Here is the Anointed One!’ or ‘There he is!’ do not believe it.
For false messiahs and false prophets will arise and will perform great signs and wonders so as to mislead, if possible, even the chosen ones.
Look, I have told you ahead of time.
So if they say to you, ‘Look, he is in the wilderness,’ do not go out there; or ‘Look, he is in the private inner rooms,’ do not believe it.
For just as the lightning comes from the east and flashes as far as the west, so will be the royal presence of the Son of Man.
Wherever the carcass is, there the vultures will gather.
Immediately after the ordeal of those days, the sun will be darkened, and the moon will not give its light; the stars will fall from the sky, and the powers of the heavens will be shaken.

Then the sign of the Son of Man will appear in heaven, and all the tribes of the land will beat their breasts in mourning, and they will see the Son of Man coming on the clouds of heaven with power and great glory.
And he will send out his messengers with a great trumpet blast, and they will gather his chosen ones from the four winds, from one end of the heavens to the other.
Now learn this analogy from the fig tree: as soon as its branch becomes tender and puts out its leaves, you know that summer is near.
In the same way, when you see all these things, you know that he is near, right at the door.
