Truly I tell you, this generation will certainly not pass away until all these things take place.
Heaven and earth will pass away, but my words will never pass away.
But concerning that day and hour, no one knows—not even the messengers of heaven, nor the Son—except the Father alone.
For just as the days of Noah were, so will be the royal presence of the Son of Man.
For in those days before the flood, they were eating and drinking, marrying and giving in marriage, right up to the day Noah entered the ark.
They knew nothing until the flood came and swept them all away. That is how the royal presence of the Son of Man will be.
Then two men will be in the field; one is taken and one is left.
Two women will be grinding grain at the hand-mill; one is taken and one is left.
Therefore, stay awake, because you do not know on what day your Lord is coming.
But understand this: if the master of the house had known in which watch of the night the thief was coming, he would have stayed awake and would not have let his house be broken into.
For this reason, you also must be ready, because the Son of Man is coming at an hour you do not expect.
Who then is the faithful and sensible servant whom the master put in charge of his household staff to give them their food at the proper time?
Blessed is 그 servant whom his master finds doing so when he arrives.
Truly I tell you, he will put him in charge of all his possessions.
But if that wicked servant says in his heart, ‘My master is taking his time,’
and he begins to beat his fellow servants, and eats and drinks with drunkards,
the master of that servant will arrive on a day he does not expect and at an hour he does not know.
He will cut him in two and assign him a place with the performers. In that place, there will be weeping and gnashing of teeth.”[/JESUS]

chapters.notes:
**"Royal presence" (v. 3, 27, 37, 39)**: The Greek *parousia* often meant "coming" or "arrival," but in the Greco-Roman world, it was a technical term for the formal state visit of a king or high official to a city. It implies both the arrival and the subsequent period of presence.

**"Consummation of the age" (v. 3)**: The Greek *synteleia* suggests a "bringing together" or "completion" of all things, rather than just a chronological "end."

**"Anointed One" (v. 5, 23)**: *Christos* is the Greek translation of the Hebrew *Mashiach* (Messiah). Using "Anointed One" maintains the titular and Jewish character of the claim being made by these figures.

**"Birth-throes" (v. 8)**: The Greek *ōdinōn* refers specifically to labor pains. In Jewish eschatology, "the birth pangs of the Messiah" (Hevlei ha-Mashiach) was a technical term for the period of suffering immediately preceding the arrival of the Messianic age.

**"Tripped up" (v. 10)**: *Skandalisthesontai* refers to the trigger of a trap. It means to be caused to stumble or to have one’s faith destroyed by an obstacle.

**"Appalling desecration" (v. 15)**: *Bdelygma tēs erēmōseōs* (Septuagint translation of Daniel’s "abomination of desolation") refers to a ritual or religious object that is so foul it causes the temple to be abandoned or makes it a desert.

**"Let the reader understand" (v. 15)**: Most scholars view this as an authorial aside to the reader of the Gospel, rather than words spoken by Jesus. It highlights the urgency of interpreting the "desecration" correctly in light of current events (likely the Roman siege of Jerusalem).

**"No human being" (v. 22)**: The Greek *pasa sarx* (all flesh) is a Hebraism/Aramaism meaning "all humanity."

**"Vultures" (v. 28)**: While *aetoi* can mean "eagles," it frequently refers to griffon vultures in a Palestinian context, especially when associated with a carcass (*ptōma*). There may be a subtle wordplay here on the Roman eagle standards (aquilae) that surrounded Jerusalem during the siege.

**"Tribes of the land" (v. 30)**: *Tēs gēs* can mean "the earth" or "the land" (Israel). Given the allusion to Zechariah 12:12, the mourning of the tribes of Israel is the primary image.

**"Messengers" (v. 31, 36)**: *Angeloi* means messengers. While usually celestial beings (angels), the term focuses on their function of carrying out the King's gathering.

**"This generation" (v. 34)**: *Genea* refers to the people living at the same time. Jesus is linking the destruction of the temple (vv. 1-2) to the timeframe of his contemporaries.

**"Broken into" (v. 43)**: The Greek *dioruchthēnai* literally means "to be dug through," reflecting the common first-century mud-brick construction of houses.

**"Performers" (v. 51)**: See translation guidelines on *hypokritai*. These are people whose lives are an act or a theatrical display, contrasted with the "faithful and sensible" servant.

**"Cut him in two" (v. 51)**: *Dichotomēsei* is a graphic term for dismemberment. While some suggest it is an idiom for a severe beating, the literal rendering captures the shocking severity of the master’s judgment.

verses.text: “In that day, the Kingdom of the Heavens will be like ten young bridesmaids who took their torches and went out to meet the bridegroom.
Five of them were foolish, and five were sensible.
For when the foolish ones took their torches, they did not take extra oil with them;
but the sensible ones took flasks of oil along with their torches.
When the bridegroom was delayed, they all became drowsy and fell asleep.
But in the middle of the night, a shout rang out: ‘Look! The bridegroom! Come out to meet him!’
Then all those bridesmaids woke up and prepared their torches.
The foolish ones said to the sensible ones, [SPEAKER:Foolish Bridesmaids]‘Give us some of your oil, because our torches are going out.’[/SPEAKER]
But the sensible ones answered, [SPEAKER:Sensible Bridesmaids]‘No, there certainly won’t be enough for both us and you. Go instead to the dealers and buy some for yourselves.’[/SPEAKER]
But while they were going away to buy it, the bridegroom arrived. Those who were ready went in with him to the wedding feast, and the door was shut.
Later, the rest of the bridesmaids arrived and said, [SPEAKER:Foolish Bridesmaids]‘Lord, lord, open the door for us!’[/SPEAKER]
But he replied, [SPEAKER:Bridegroom]‘Truly I tell you, I do not know you.’[/SPEAKER]
Therefore, stay alert, because you do not know the day or the hour.
For it is just like a man going on a journey, who called his own slaves and entrusted his possessions to them.
To one he gave five talents, to another two, and to another one—to each according to his own specific ability. Then he left on his journey.
Immediately, the one who had received the five talents went and put them to work and gained five more.
In the same way, the one with the two talents gained two more.
But the one who had received the one talent went off, dug a hole in the ground, and hid his master’s silver.
After a long time, the master of those slaves returned and settled accounts with them.
The one who had received the five talents came forward and brought five more, saying, [SPEAKER:Slave 1]‘Master, you entrusted five talents to me; see, I have gained five more talents.’[/SPEAKER]

His master said to him, [SPEAKER:Master]‘Well done, good and faithful slave! You were faithful with a few things; I will put you in charge of many things. Enter into the joy of your master.’[/SPEAKER]
The one with the two talents also came forward and said, [SPEAKER:Slave 2]‘Master, you entrusted two talents to me; see, I have gained two more talents.’[/SPEAKER]

His master said to him, [SPEAKER:Master]‘Well done, good and faithful slave! You were faithful with a few things; I will put you in charge of many things. Enter into the joy of your master.’[/SPEAKER]

Then the one who had received the one talent came forward and said, [SPEAKER:Slave 3]‘Master, I knew you to be a demanding man, harvesting where you did not sow and gathering where you did not winnow.
Because I was afraid, I went off and hid your talent in the ground. Look, you have what belongs to you.’[/SPEAKER]
But his master answered him, [SPEAKER:Master]‘You wicked and lazy slave! You knew, did you, that I harvest where I did not sow and gather where I did not winnow?
Then you should have invested my silver with the bankers, and when I returned, I would have received my own money back with interest.
Therefore, take the talent from him and give it to the one who has the ten talents.
For to everyone who has, more will be given, and he will have an abundance; but from the one who does not have, even what he has will be taken away.
And throw this useless slave into the darkness outside; in that place there will be weeping and gnashing of teeth.’[/SPEAKER]
When the Son of Man comes in his glory, and all the angels with him, then he will sit on his glorious throne.
All the nations will be gathered before him, and he will separate them from one another, just as a shepherd separates the sheep from the young goats.
He will put the sheep on his right, but the goats on his left.
Then the King will say to those on his right, [SPEAKER:The King]‘Come, you who are blessed by my Father, inherit the kingdom prepared for you from the foundation of the world.
For I was hungry and you gave me something to eat; I was thirsty and you gave me something to drink; I was a stranger and you took me in;
naked and you clothed me; I was sick and you looked after me; I was in prison and you came to visit me.’[/SPEAKER]
Then the righteous will answer him, [SPEAKER:The Righteous]‘Lord, when did we see you hungry and feed you, or thirsty and give you something to drink?
When did we see you a stranger and take you in, or naked and clothe you?
When did we see you sick or in prison and come to visit you?’[/SPEAKER]
And the King will answer them, [SPEAKER:The King]‘Truly I tell you, to the extent that you did it for one of the least of these brothers and sisters of mine, you did it for me.’[/SPEAKER]
Then he will also say to those on his left, [SPEAKER:The King]‘Depart from me, you who are under a curse, into the eternal fire prepared for the slanderer and his angels.
For I was hungry and you gave me nothing to eat; I was thirsty and you gave me nothing to drink;
I was a stranger and you did not take me in; naked and you did not clothe me; sick and in prison and you did not look after me.’[/SPEAKER]
Then they themselves will answer, [SPEAKER:The Cursed]‘Lord, when did we see you hungry or thirsty or a stranger or naked or sick or in prison and did not minister to you?’[/SPEAKER]
Then he will answer them, [SPEAKER:The King]‘Truly I tell you, to the extent that you did not do it for one of the least of these, you did not do it for me.’[/SPEAKER]
And these will go away into eternal punishment, but the righteous into eternal life.”[/JESUS]

chapters.notes:
**"Torches" (v. 1, 3, 7)**: The Greek *lampas* in a wedding context refers to outdoor torches (usually rags wrapped around a stick and soaked in oil) rather than the small ceramic indoor oil lamps (*lychnos*). This explains why they needed "flasks" of extra oil; torches consume fuel much faster than small lamps.

**"Sensible" (v. 2, 4, 9)**: *Phronimoi* is often translated as "wise," but it specifically denotes practical Steiner-like prudence, foresight, and sound judgment rather than abstract wisdom (*sophia*).

**"Talents" (v. 15-28)**: A "talent" (*talanton*) was not an innate skill, but a massive unit of weight/currency. One talent of silver was roughly equivalent to 6,000 denarii—nearly 20 years of wages for a common laborer. Even the slave with "one" was entrusted with a fortune.

**"Winnow" (v. 24, 26)**: *Dieskorpisas* refers to the process of scattering grain to let the wind blow away the chaff. The slave’s accusation is that the master takes profit from even the most marginal agricultural activities where he put in no effort.

**"Slanderer" (v. 41)**: The Greek *diabolos* (the Devil) literally means "the slanderer" or "the accuser." In a passage focused on judgment and the "gnashing of teeth" (often associated with social or legal exclusion), the literal meaning of the title is significant.

**"Eternal" (v. 41, 46)**: The Greek *aiōnios* refers to the *aiōn* (age). While it carries the sense of "everlasting" in traditional English, to a first-century ear, it specifically meant "belonging to the age to come."

**"The least of these" (v. 40, 45)**: In Matthew's Gospel, "these brothers [and sisters] of mine" typically refers to the disciples or the community of believers (cf. Matthew 12:48-50, 28:10). The judgment is based on how the nations treated Jesus's representatives.

verses.text: And it happened that when Jesus had finished all these words, he said to his disciples,
[JESUS]"You know that after two days the Passover is coming, and the Son of Man is being handed over to be crucified."[/JESUS]
Then the chief priests and the elders of the people gathered in the courtyard of the high priest, whose name was Caiaphas,
and they plotted together to arrest Jesus by treachery and kill him.
But they were saying, [CROWD]"Not during the festival, so that there will not be a riot among the people."[/CROWD]
Now while Jesus was in Bethany in the house of Simon the Leper,
a woman came to him with an alabaster jar of extremely precious scented oil, and she poured it over his head as he reclined at the table.
But when the disciples saw it, they were indignant and said, [CROWD]"Why this waste?
For this could have been sold for a great deal and the money given to the poor."[/CROWD]
But Jesus, aware of this, said to them, [JESUS]"Why are you bothering the woman? She has done a beautiful deed for me.
For you always have the poor with you, but you do not always have me.
By pouring this scented oil on my body, she did it to prepare me for burial.
Truly I tell you, wherever this good news is proclaimed in the whole world, what she has done will also be told in memory of her."[/JESUS]
Then one of the twelve, the one called Judas Iscariot, went to the chief priests
and said, [SPEAKER:Judas]"What are you willing to give me if I hand him over to you?"[/SPEAKER] And they weighed out thirty pieces of silver for him.
From then on, he began looking for a favorable opportunity to hand him over.
On the first day of Unleavened Bread, the disciples came to Jesus, saying, [CROWD]"Where do you want us to make preparations for you to eat the Passover?"[/CROWD]
He said, [JESUS]"Go into the city to a certain man and tell him, 'The Teacher says: [JESUS]"My appointed time is near; I am keeping the Passover at your house with my disciples."[/JESUS]'"[/JESUS]
And the disciples did as Jesus directed them, and they prepared the Passover.
When evening came, he was reclining at the table with the twelve disciples.
While they were eating, he said, [JESUS]"Truly I tell you, one of you will hand me over."[/JESUS]
Deeply grieved, each one of them began to say to him, [SPEAKER:Disciples]"Surely not I, Lord?"[/SPEAKER]
He answered, [JESUS]"The one who has dipped his hand into the bowl with me—this is the one who will hand me over.
The Son of Man goes just as it is written about him, but woe to that man by whom the Son of Man is handed over! It would have been better for that man if he had never been born."[/JESUS]
Judas, the one handing him over, answered and said, [SPEAKER:Judas]"Surely not I, Rabbi?"[/SPEAKER] He said to him, [JESUS]"You have said it yourself."[/JESUS]
While they were eating, Jesus took bread, and after pronouncing the blessing, he broke it and gave it to the disciples, saying, [JESUS]"Take, eat; this is my body."[/JESUS]
Then he took a cup, and after giving thanks, he gave it to them, saying, [JESUS]"Drink from it, all of you;
for this is my blood of the covenant, which is being poured out for many for the forgiveness of sins.
I tell you, I will never again drink of this fruit of the vine until that day when I drink it new with you in my Father's kingdom."[/JESUS]
And after singing the hymn, they went out to the Mount of Olives.
Then Jesus said to them, [JESUS]"You will all fall away because of me this night, for it is written: [SCRIPTURE]'I will strike the shepherd, and the sheep of the flock will be scattered.'[/SCRIPTURE]
But after I have been raised, I will go ahead of you into Galilee."[/JESUS]
Peter answered and said to him, [SPEAKER:Peter]"Even if everyone else falls away because of you, I will never fall away!"[/SPEAKER]
Jesus said to him, [JESUS]"Truly I tell you, this very night, before the rooster crows, you will deny me three times."[/JESUS]
Peter said to him, [SPEAKER:Peter]"Even if I must die with you, I will never deny you!"[/SPEAKER] And all the disciples said the same thing.
Then Jesus came with them to a place called Gethsemane, and he said to the disciples, [JESUS]"Sit here while I go over there and pray."[/JESUS]
Taking along Peter and the two sons of Zebedee, he began to be filled with grief and distress.
Then he said to them, [JESUS]"My soul is deeply grieved, even to the point of death. Stay here and keep watch with me."[/JESUS]
Going forward a little, he fell on his face, praying and saying, [JESUS]"My Father, if it is possible, let this cup pass from me; yet not as I will, but as you will."[/JESUS]
He came to the disciples and found them sleeping, and he said to Peter, [JESUS]"So, were you not strong enough to keep watch with me for a single hour?
Keep watch and pray so that you do not enter into the ordeal. The spirit is willing, but the flesh is weak."[/JESUS]
Again, for a second time, he went away and prayed, saying, [JESUS]"My Father, if this cannot pass unless I drink it, let your will be done."[/JESUS]
And coming again, he found them sleeping, for their eyes were heavy.
So leaving them again, he went away and prayed for the third time, saying the same thing once more.
Then he came to the disciples and said to them, [JESUS]"Are you still sleeping and resting? Look, the hour has come near, and the Son of Man is being handed over into the hands of sinners.
Get up, let us be going. Look, the one handing me over is near."[/JESUS]
While he was still speaking, look—Judas, one of the twelve, arrived, and with him a large crowd with swords and clubs, sent from the chief priests and the elders of the people.
Now the one handing him over had given them a sign, saying, [SPEAKER:Judas]"The one I kiss is the man; arrest him."[/SPEAKER]
Immediately he went up to Jesus and said, [SPEAKER:Judas]"Greetings, Rabbi!"[/SPEAKER] and he kissed him fervently.
Jesus said to him, [JESUS]"Friend, do what you are here for."[/JESUS] Then they came forward, laid hands on Jesus, and arrested him.
And look, one of those with Jesus reached out his hand, drew his sword, and striking the servant of the high priest, cut off his ear.
Then Jesus said to him, [JESUS]"Put your sword back into its place, for all who take up the sword will perish by the sword.
Or do you think that I cannot appeal to my Father, and he will at once provide me with more than twelve legions of angels?
How then would the scriptures be fulfilled that say it must happen this way?"[/JESUS]

In that hour Jesus said to the crowds, [JESUS]"Have you come out with swords and clubs to capture me as you would an insurrectionist? Day after day I sat in the temple teaching, and you did not arrest me.
But all this has happened so that the scriptures of the prophets would be fulfilled."[/JESUS] Then all the disciples deserted him and fled.
Those who had arrested Jesus led him away to Caiaphas the high priest, where the scholars of the law and the elders had gathered.
But Peter followed him at a distance as far as the courtyard of the high priest, and going inside, he sat with the attendants to see the outcome.
Now the chief priests and the entire High Council were looking for false testimony against Jesus so that they might put him to death,
but they found none, though many false witnesses came forward. Finally, two came forward
and said, [CROWD]"This man said, 'I am able to destroy the sanctuary of God and rebuild it in three days.'"[/CROWD]
The high priest stood up and said to him, [SPEAKER:Caiaphas]"Have you no answer? What is this they are testifying against you?"[/SPEAKER]
But Jesus remained silent. Then the high priest said to him, [SPEAKER:Caiaphas]"I adjure you by the living God: tell us if you are the Christ, the Son of God."[/SPEAKER]
Jesus said to him, [JESUS]"You have said it yourself. But I tell you: from now on you will see the Son of Man sitting at the right hand of the Power and coming on the clouds of heaven."[/JESUS]
Then the high priest tore his robes, saying, [SPEAKER:Caiaphas]"He has blasphemed! Why do we still need witnesses? Look, you have now heard the blasphemy.
What is your verdict?"[/SPEAKER] They answered and said, [CROWD]"He is deserving of death!"[/CROWD]
Then they spat in his face and struck him with their fists, and others slapped him,
saying, [CROWD]"Prophesy to us, you Christ! Who is the one who hit you?"[/CROWD]
Now Peter was sitting outside in the courtyard. A servant girl came up to him and said, [SPEAKER:Servant Girl]"You also were with Jesus the Galilean."[/SPEAKER]
But he denied it before everyone, saying, [SPEAKER:Peter]"I do not know what you are talking about."[/SPEAKER]
When he went out to the gateway, another girl saw him and said to those who were there, [SPEAKER:Servant Girl]"This man was with Jesus the Nazarene."[/SPEAKER]
Again he denied it with an oath: [SPEAKER:Peter]"I do not know the man!"[/SPEAKER]
After a little while, the bystanders came up and said to Peter, [CROWD]"Truly you are also one of them, for even your accent gives you away."[/CROWD]
Then he began to call down curses on himself and to swear, [SPEAKER:Peter]"I do not know the man!"[/SPEAKER] And immediately a rooster crowed.
And Peter remembered the word Jesus had spoken: [JESUS]"Before the rooster crows, you will deny me three times."[/JESUS] And he went outside and wept bitterly.

chapters.notes:
**"Handed over" (v. 2, 15, 16, 21, etc.)**: The Greek *paradidōmi* is often translated as "betray," but its primary meaning is "to hand over" or "deliver." In Matthew, this term carries deep theological weight, echoing the "handing over" of the Suffering Servant and the divine necessity of Jesus’s path.

**"Scented oil" (v. 7)**: The Greek *muron* refers to a thick, fragrant ointment or oil, much more substantial and costly than modern "perfume."

**"Beautiful deed" (v. 10)**: *Ergon kalon* is often "good work," but *kalos* denotes beauty, nobility, and moral excellence. Jesus is defending the aesthetic and devotional value of her act against pure pragmatism.

**"Thirty pieces of silver" (v. 15)**: This likely refers to Tyrian shekels (staters), the standard for the Temple tax. The amount is a specific allusion to Zechariah 11:12 and the value of a slave in Exodus 21:32.

**"A certain man" (v. 18)**: *Ton deina* is a colloquial Greek idiom used when a speaker knows a name but chooses not to say it, or assumes the listener knows who is meant.

**"You have said it yourself" (v. 25, 64)**: This translates the Greek *sy eipas*. It is a Semitic idiom that affirms the statement while placing the responsibility for the words on the questioner. It is a nuanced "Yes," but one that refuses to use the questioner's own framing.

**"The Power" (v. 64)**: This is a common first-century Jewish circumlocution for God, used to avoid pronouncing the divine name. A contemporary reader would immediately recognize "the Power" as a title for the Almighty.

**"Insurrectionist" (v. 55)**: The Greek *lēstēs* means more than a "thief" or "robber"; it was the term used for political rebels or social bandits (like Barabbas). Jesus is pointing out the absurdity of treating a teacher as a violent revolutionary.

**"The Ordeal" (v. 41)**: While *peirasmos* is often "temptation," in this eschatological context (the Garden of Gethsemane), it refers to the "great trial" or "ordeal" that is coming upon Jesus and his followers.

**"Sanctuary" (v. 61)**: The word *naos* refers specifically to the inner temple building (the Holy Place and Holy of Holies), rather than the entire temple complex (*hieron*).

verses.text: When the first light of morning came, all the chief priests and the elders of the people reached a formal decision against Jesus to have him executed.
After binding him, they led him away and handed him over to Pilate, the governor.
Then Judas, the one who had handed him over, saw that Jesus had been condemned. Seized with remorse, he brought the thirty silver shekels back to the chief priests and elders,
saying, [SPEAKER:Judas]“I have sinned by handing over innocent blood.”[/SPEAKER] But they said, [CROWD]“What is that to us? That is your concern.”[/CROWD]
He flung the silver pieces into the sanctuary and retreated; then he went away and hanged himself.
The chief priests took the silver pieces and said, [CROWD]“It is not permitted to put these into the *korbanan*, since it is the price of blood.”[/CROWD]
So after reaching a decision, they used the money to buy the Potter’s Field as a burial place for foreigners.
For this reason, that field has been called the Field of Blood to this very day.

Then what was spoken through Jeremiah the prophet was fulfilled, saying: [SCRIPTURE]“And they took the thirty silver shekels, the price of the one who had been valued, whom some of the sons of Israel had set a price upon,
and they gave them for the potter’s field, just as the Lord commanded me.”[/SCRIPTURE]
Now Jesus stood before the governor, and the governor questioned him, saying, [SPEAKER:Pilate]“Are you the King of the Jews?”[/SPEAKER] Jesus said, [JESUS]“You are the one saying it.”[/JESUS]
But while he was being accused by the chief priests and elders, he gave no answer.
Then Pilate said to him, [SPEAKER:Pilate]“Do you not hear how many things they are testifying against you?”[/SPEAKER]
And he did not answer him, not even to a single word, so that the governor was greatly amazed.
Now at the feast, the governor was accustomed to releasing one prisoner to the crowd, whomever they wanted.
At that time they were holding a notorious prisoner called Jesus Barabbas.
So when they had gathered, Pilate said to them, [SPEAKER:Pilate]“Whom do you want me to release for you: Jesus Barabbas, or Jesus who is called the Christ?”[/SPEAKER]
For he knew that they had handed him over because of envy.

While he was sitting on the judgment seat, his wife sent a message to him, saying, [SPEAKER:Pilate's Wife]“Have nothing to do with that righteous man, for I have suffered much today in a dream because of him.”[/SPEAKER]
But the chief priests and the elders persuaded the crowds to ask for Barabbas and to have Jesus destroyed.
The governor answered them, [SPEAKER:Pilate]“Which of the two do you want me to release for you?”[/SPEAKER] They said, [CROWD]“Barabbas!”[/CROWD]
Pilate said to them, [SPEAKER:Pilate]“Then what should I do with Jesus who is called the Christ?”[/SPEAKER] They all said, [CROWD]“Let him be crucified!”[/CROWD]
He said, [SPEAKER:Pilate]“Why? What evil has he done?”[/SPEAKER] But they kept shouting all the louder, [CROWD]“Let him be crucified!”[/CROWD]

When Pilate saw that he was gaining nothing, but rather that a riot was starting, he took water and washed his hands in front of the crowd, saying, [SPEAKER:Pilate]“I am innocent of this blood; you see to it yourselves.”[/SPEAKER]
And all the people answered, [CROWD]“His blood be on us and on our children!”[/CROWD]
Then he released Barabbas to them; but after having Jesus flogged with the Roman *flagellum*, he handed him over to be crucified.
Then the governor’s soldiers took Jesus into the Praetorium and gathered the whole battalion around him.
They stripped him and put a scarlet military cloak around him,
and after weaving a crown out of thorns, they placed it on his head and put a reed-staff in his right hand. They knelt before him and mocked him, saying, [CROWD]“Hail, King of the Jews!”[/CROWD]
They spat on him, took the reed-staff, and kept striking him on the head.
When they had finished mocking him, they took the cloak off him, put his own clothes back on him, and led him away to be crucified.
As they were going out, they found a man from Cyrene named Simon; they impressed this man into service to carry Jesus’s cross.
And when they came to a place called Golgotha (which means "Place of a Skull"),
they gave him wine mixed with gall to drink; but after tasting it, he refused to drink.
When they had crucified him, they divided his clothes among themselves by casting lots,
and they sat down there to keep watch over him.
Above his head they placed the written charge against him: THIS IS JESUS, THE KING OF THE JEWS.
At that time two insurgents were crucified with him, one on the right and one on the left.
Those passing by hurled insults at him, shaking their heads
and saying, [CROWD]“You who would destroy the sanctuary and build it in three days, save yourself! If you are the Son of God, come down from the cross!”[/CROWD]

In the same way, the chief priests, along with the scribes and elders, mocked him, saying, [CROWD]“He saved others; he cannot save himself! He is the King of Israel; let him come down now from the cross, and we will believe in him.
He trusts in God; let God rescue him now if he wants him! For he said, ‘I am God’s Son.’”[/CROWD]
Even the insurgents who were crucified with him were insulting him in the same way.
From the sixth hour, darkness came over all the land until the ninth hour.
About the ninth hour, Jesus cried out with a loud voice, saying, [JESUS]“Eli, Eli, lema sabachthani?”[/JESUS]—that is, [JESUS]“My God, my God, why have you abandoned me?”[/JESUS]
When some of those standing there heard it, they said, [CROWD]“This man is calling for Elijah.”[/CROWD]
Immediately one of them ran and took a sponge, filled it with sour wine, put it on a reed, and gave him a drink.
But the rest said, [CROWD]“Wait, let’s see if Elijah comes to save him.”[/CROWD]
Then Jesus, after crying out again with a loud voice, yielded up his spirit.
And behold, the curtain of the sanctuary was torn in two from top to bottom. The earth shook, the rocks were split,
and the tombs were opened. Many bodies of the holy ones who had fallen asleep were raised;
and coming out of the tombs after his resurrection, they entered the holy city and appeared to many.
When the centurion and those with him who were keeping watch over Jesus saw the earthquake and what was happening, they were terrified and said, [CROWD]“Truly this man was a son of God!”[/CROWD]
Many women were there watching from a distance, who had followed Jesus from Galilee while ministering to him.
Among them were Mary Magdalene, and Mary the mother of James and Joseph, and the mother of the sons of Zebedee.
When evening came, a rich man from Arimathea named Joseph arrived, who had himself become a disciple of Jesus.
This man went to Pilate and asked for the body of Jesus. Then Pilate ordered it to be given to him.
Joseph took the body, wrapped it in a clean linen shroud,
and laid it in his own new tomb which he had cut out of the rock. He rolled a large stone against the entrance of the tomb and went away.
Mary Magdalene and the other Mary were there, sitting opposite the grave.
The next day, which is the day after the Preparation, the chief priests and the Pharisees gathered before Pilate
and said, [CROWD]“Sir, we remember that while he was still alive, that imposter said, ‘After three days I will be raised.’

Therefore, order the grave to be secured until the third day, so that his disciples do not come and steal him and tell the people, ‘He was raised from the dead,’ and the last deception will be worse than the first.”[/CROWD]
Pilate said to them, [SPEAKER:Pilate]“You have a guard. Go, make it as secure as you know how.”[/SPEAKER]
So they went and secured the grave by sealing the stone and posting the guard.

chapters.notes:
**"Formal decision" (v. 1)**: The Greek *symboulion elabon* implies a deliberative process resulting in a official resolution or "counsel," rather than just "taking advice."

**"Handing over" (v. 2, 3, 4, 18)**: The verb *paradidōmi* is the central motif of this chapter. While often translated as "betray," its primary meaning is to "hand over" or "deliver." Using "handing over" consistently preserves the structural connection between Judas’s action and the Jewish leaders' action toward Pilate.

**"Sanctuary" (v. 5, 51)**: The word *naon* refers specifically to the inner temple building, the Holy Place or Holy of Holies, as opposed to *hieron*, the general Temple precinct.

**"Korbanan" (v. 6)**: This is a Greek transliteration of the Aramaic/Hebrew term for the Temple treasury or the place for offerings dedicated to God (*korban*).

**"Jesus Barabbas" (v. 16, 17)**: Following the SBLGNT and early manuscripts (and supported by some scholars as the original reading), the name "Jesus" is included before Barabbas. This creates a powerful literary and thematic contrast between "Jesus the Son of the Father" (the literal meaning of Barabbas) and "Jesus the Christ."

**"You are the one saying it" (v. 11)**: *Sy legeis* is an enigmatic response. It is not a straightforward "Yes," but rather places the burden of the claim on the speaker—effectively saying, "Those are your words."

**"Roman flagellum" (v. 26)**: The Greek *phragellōsas* is a loanword from the Latin *flagellare*. This was not a simple beating but a brutal Roman scourging using a whip with weighted lashes.

**"Insurgents" (v. 38, 44)**: *Lēstai* is often translated as "thieves" or "robbers," but in first-century Judea, it frequently referred to social bandits or insurrectionists—political rebels against Rome. Given they are being crucified (a Roman punishment for treason and sedition), "insurgents" captures the political reality better than "thieves."

**"Abandoned" (v. 46)**: *Egkatelipes* means to leave behind in a state of need or to forsake. "Abandoned" conveys the visceral sense of being left alone in distress.

**"A son of God" (v. 54)**: The Greek *theou huios* lacks the definite article. While Matthew’s readers would understand this as "The Son of God," the Roman centurion would likely have meant "a divine being" or "a son of a god" in a Greco-Roman context. The translation "a son of God" allows for both the centurion’s immediate reaction and the reader’s theological understanding.

**"Imposter" (v. 63)**: *Planos* means a deceiver, wanderer, or charlatan. It reflects the elite's view of Jesus as a messianic pretender leading the people astray.

**"Guard" (v. 65, 66)**: The Greek *koustōdian* is a loanword from the Latin *custodia*, referring to a Roman guard unit. This emphasizes that the security was likely provided by Roman soldiers under Pilate's authority.

verses.text: After the Sabbath, as the first day of the week was beginning to dawn, Mary Magdalene and the other Mary went to gaze upon the tomb.
Suddenly, there was a violent earthquake, for an angel of the Lord descended from heaven, came forward, rolled back the stone, and sat upon it.
His appearance was like lightning and his clothing white as snow.
The guards shook from fear of him and became like dead men.
But the angel said to the women, [ANGEL]"Do not be afraid. I know that you are looking for Jesus, the one who was crucified.
He is not here; he has been raised, just as he said. Come, see the place where he was lying.
Then go quickly and tell his disciples: ‘He has been raised from the dead, and behold, he is going ahead of you into Galilee; you will see him there.’ Look, I have told you."[/ANGEL]
So they departed quickly from the tomb with fear and great joy, and ran to report this to his disciples.
And behold, Jesus met them and said, [JESUS]"Greetings!"[/JESUS] They came to him, took hold of his feet, and bowed down in worship before him.
Then Jesus said to them, [JESUS]"Do not be afraid. Go, report to my brothers that they should leave for Galilee, and they will see me there."[/JESUS]
While they were on their way, look—some of the guard went into the city and reported to the chief priests everything that had happened.
After the priests had met with the elders and reached a decision, they gave a large sum of silver to the soldiers
and told them, [SPEAKER:Chief Priests]"You are to say, ‘His disciples came during the night and stole him while we were sleeping.’
And if this is heard before the governor, we will satisfy him and keep you out of trouble."[/SPEAKER]
So they took the silver and did as they were instructed. And this story has been spread among the Jews until this very day.
Now the eleven disciples went to Galilee, to the mountain where Jesus had directed them.
When they saw him, they bowed down in worship, though some hesitated.
Jesus came forward and spoke to them, saying: [JESUS]"All authority in heaven and on earth has been given to me.
Go, therefore, and make disciples of all the nations, baptizing them into the name of the Father and of the Son and of the Holy Spirit,
teaching them to observe everything I have commanded you. And behold, I am with you always, even until the completion of the age."[/JESUS]

chapters.notes:
**"After the Sabbath... beginning to dawn" (v. 1)**: The Greek *opse* with the genitive typically means "after" in this period, rather than "late on." Matthew uses the Hebraic/Aramaic idiom *mia sabbaton* ("one of the Sabbath") to refer to the first day of the week (Sunday).

**"Gaze upon" (v. 1)**: The verb *theōrēsai* implies more than a casual look; it suggests a purposeful observation or beholding. 

**"Violent earthquake / shook" (v. 2, 4)**: The Greek uses the noun *seismos* (earthquake) and the verb *eseisthēsan* (shook) from the same root. This literary connection highlights that the guards were "quaked" by the same divine power that moved the earth.

**"Has been raised" (v. 6, 7)**: The verb *ēgerthē* is a "divine passive." It indicates that Jesus did not simply "rise" by his own power, but was raised by the action of God the Father.

**"Greetings!" (v. 9)**: The Greek *chairete* is the standard greeting (literally "Rejoice!"). In a Jewish context, this would likely correspond to the Aramaic/Hebrew *Shalom*, but Matthew’s choice of the Greek imperative preserves the atmosphere of joy surrounding the resurrection.

**"Bowed down in worship" (v. 9, 17)**: The verb *prosekynēsan* describes the physical act of prostrating oneself or kneeling. In this context, it carries the full weight of religious adoration, acknowledging Jesus’s divine authority.

**"Keep you out of trouble" (v. 14)**: The Greek *amerimnous* literally means "without care" or "free from anxiety." In this legal/military context, it means the religious leaders will ensure the soldiers face no professional consequences (like the death penalty for sleeping on watch).

**"Hesitated" (v. 17)**: The verb *edistasan* suggests a state of wavering or being of two minds. While often translated as "doubted," it captures the psychological tension of the disciples seeing someone they knew was dead.

**"Into the name" (v. 19)**: The use of the preposition *eis* (into) rather than *en* (in) is significant. It suggests a change of status or ownership—the person being baptized is being brought into a covenant relationship with and under the authority of the Trinity.

**"Completion of the age" (v. 20)**: The phrase *synteleias tou aiōnos* refers to the consummation of the current era of human history, marking the transition to the world to come. It implies a "filling up" or "finishing" of time.
